I wonder how Matt Damon did it so well. I'd rather assume that he did, for himself once had a similar experience in life, than that he simply achieved this by outstanding acting skills. The latter would be nearly impossible to do, having known for myself what this type of pain was really like.

Affleck and Damon are an unbelievable team, both in acting and writing this movie. Robin Williams sure as hell deserves the Oscar he got for his role here, and the rest of the cast all did a great job. The movie has a very smooth and well-structured storyline. No waste scenes, one step tightly after another, unfolding the character's emotion progresses. When you finally witness Williams's role gets to the soul of Damon's role with a number of "It's not your fault", your icy wall if you have one too, shattered with it.

Most soulful movie I've ever seen. For me it's mostly because I suffered similar bruises myself, but note this, you do not need such thing to appreciate it. All you need to be, is a true human being.

Go see Good Will Hunting.

title: What do you want to do...
review:
Before I go on with my ranting, I want to first mention that I write this message with the intention of making known my belief of what this movie is about and what sort of connection it's attempting to make. One who's never seen this movie should feel that this message tells you what the central theme of this movie is, whereas for the ones who've seen it, this should offer nothing more than another point of view.

I feel the central idea of this movie is to put forward a person (Will) with an infinite ("bound by nothing") potential and at the same time an inner demon that held him back from the world. And what Sean (Robin Williams) offered him is courage and he taught Will that part of living life is to have this courage to face his inner demons and choose his own path without fear.

***What do you want to do?***

One of the major theme in this movie is this very question. By putting will forward and showing that with all of his genius, he's lost when facing with this simple question. What do we want to do? The point of this question is not to get an answer as simple as "I want to be a lawyer or a doctor". I feel the point of this question is the question itself. It asks you to give an answer that ,despite all the genius and all the power of reason and logic, you can not find a definitive answer to. It asks you to understand yourself, to search for something that you can never truly know you've found. It involves devotion,love,risk, loss and disappointment, something Will will never dare to face. When Sean asked Will this question, he wasn't expecting will to answer it with a definitive answer, but Will is thinking of it as a question and he can come up with all the reasonable answers in the world, they would still be wrong, because for will, he's too scared to face his own inner demon and too confused to know what to do with himself. What Sean offered will is the reflection of his own life. He tells will despite all the pain and loss, it's OK, because that doesn't diminish even slightly the greatness of love and life. He showed will that true loss is only when you love something more than you love yourself, and at the same time that's where true happiness emerges. It is through all the conversations and sharing Will slowly realizes that he's not alone, he has the chance to be happy if he has the courage to face down his own demon and to find his own joy (as he chased after his girlfriend at the end of the movie). What We all need is to do is to find a path and have the the courage to follow through. Most of the times we don't know if what we've chosen is the correct path, but as long as we tried, Joy and love will always be there to carpet the road of pain and loss. That is what life is all about.

***what is failure, what is success*** In this movie, there is an interesting contrast between the field metal winner and the supposedly lowly psychologist who lives and works in a small apartment. This movie offered a chance for one to think about what is true success? Is it how much money you make? The working environment? Pension? bonus? or is it as the producer of this movie believed, that there's no true success or failure, it's about what we want and to live is to feel. For those who do not know, Field Metal is a huge deal, it's probably more amazing than the Noble price for math people. This is a really interesting question, I just want to throw it out there. to write what I think would make me run out of space.

***one interesting scene*** there is a picture of a man rolling a boat inside a storm, that is my favorite scene in the entire history of movies. The use of one painting and a few words from Will entirely described the sadness of the sullen psychologist and it also offers a very unique and interesting portrait of what it means to feel completely lost and helpless. If you've felt like that before in any point in your life, You would appreciate this scene, at least that's my point of view.

Overall, This is a story of trust, courage and love. It showed the most fundamental question that someone in my age (early 20s or even late teens) should always bear in mind. and You should never miss a movie as intelligently crafted as the Good Will Hunting.

title: Better every time
review:
I'm not sure why I like "Good Will Hunting" so much. The plot is such a simple story of Will Hunting (Matt Damon), a young man with intelligence way beyond his years, yet all he is choosing to do with his life is cleaning the floors at his job and hanging out with his friends. After getting in trouble with the law, college professor Sean Maquire (Robin Williams, in his Oscar-winning role) is the only person willing to counsel him and turn his life around. Maybe I enjoy this film because I relate so well to it, as I am a college student unsure of what to do with my life. The film has rightly been described as a "slow-burner," and I would agree. It was during my second viewing that the film's greatness suddenly hit me, and I really began to like it. It entertains but also brings tears to my eyes. It has the same inspirational value as Robin Williams' earlier film "Dead Poets Society," for which he also should have won an Academy Award. Although I prefer this film, since it focuses more on inspiring a single person rather than an entire group, both movies are excellent. Maybe it's not an entirely perfect film, but watch this one (more than once if necessary) and be prepared to be moved.

***1/2 out of ****

title: A great film!
review:
Good Will Hunting is a great movie. Of all the films I have seen Matt Damon in, this is the best one. His character isn't an action hero like in the Bourne Trilogy, nor is a comical thief in the Ocean's series. He plays a youth in south Boston, driven by his fears of abandonment and a lack of trust in people. However, his unique math abilities are discovered by a college professor (Stellan Skarsgard) who gives him an opportunity to change his original lifestyle from a street punk to someone of value and good qualities.

He later sees a therapist (Robin Williams) and finds a girlfriend (Minnie Driver), who become the two benefactors that ultimately makes him into something more than he ever thought. Besides Matt Damon's Oscar nominated performance, I found Robin Williams to be fascinating. Rob won an Oscar for his role and it is rightfully deserved. He made me laugh and at times put me close to tears from the talks he has with Damon about life and change.

The additional performances by Minnie driver, Stellan Skarsgard, Ben and Casey Affleck are all wonderfully. The script by Ben and Matt is both entertaining and genius. The score by Danny Elfman was also a nice addition to film. But I give this move a 9 out of 10 because there was so much unneeded foul language. I'm used to hearing bad words, particularly in the likes of an Oliver Stone and a Martin Scorsese film, but not for something along the likes of Good Will Hunting. I guess Matt and Ben felt they needed f-bombs and other sexual dialog to make the film more real. The film would still be real without them.

title: One of the most deeply and essentially human films ever
review:
Perhaps the only thing that's beyond normal in "Good Will Hunting" is the fact that Will Hunting is a mathematical genius. The rest is about as real as a film can get while still being interesting. To be two hours about a young man and his issues and to be so good says a lot about the acting and the writing of this film: that it's very, very good.

"Hunting" stars Matt Damon as the title role, the enigma that is Will Hunting. Damon is so good at capturing the broad spectrum of his character's emotions. Hunting is written to be a psychological head case who thinks he's figured out what life's about and what people are about and Damon really shows you that. It's a role that would seemingly be played by Leonardo Di Caprio, but we all know what he was busy doing in 1997.

Hunting is a janitor at MIT and when he starts solving some of the most difficult of math equations, he gets discovered by Professor Gerald Lambeau (Stellan Skarsgard). Because Hunting is an orphan and spends most of his time around South Boston getting into trouble with his friends, the plot gets moving when the professor agrees to get Hunting out of jail time with the exceptions that he spend time on math with him and that he go to therapy. After therapy with several top shrinks fails, Hunting is taken to Sean Maguire (Robin Williams) and the two form a unique relationship. The film is in general about the psychological and social journey of Hunting as he begins to understand what life's really all about.

Just as good as Damon though are Skarsgard and of course Robin Williams, who is in a role that seems perfect for him, or at least he makes it his own very much so in this film. His character is so honest, but also very poignant and funny.

It's a simple concept really. You tell the story of a genius who was orphaned and abused as a child and you have a story of untapped potential and of letting go of the past to embrace the future. Damon and Affleck, who are responsible for the film's intelligent screenplay simply tell this in a really complex way, showing it through the relationship between Will and Sean, Sean and Professor Lambeau, and even Will and his best friend Chuckie (Ben Affleck). There's a very wide spectrum and experience there. Sometimes the dialogue does seem a bit too elitist and literary, but most of the time it's natural and just meaningful. Gus Van Sant adds some touches of his own, but this is mostly about the story and the characters, so he succeeds at his job of letting it be about them.

"Good Will Hunting" might now blow you out of the water, but it's touching because it's so human and because the characters could be any of us. Will is the extreme (lonely poor orphan math genius), but we all identify with extremes better in some way, and that's what makes this film successful.

title: awesome!
review:
i read an article about the "Good Will Hunting" in reader's digest as i fumble through the very late issues of the magazine as i had a time to sit down and relax in the midst of my nocturnal habits.so, when i got a chance to spend 126 minutes to it, i did not let it pass.

the best highlights of this movie are the performance of the two best actors-Damon and Williams. the conflict between the characters propelled the story to its incredible turning point.

the ever searching truth about life was explained in its very drastic way, yet unbearable.

the best contender for Titanic that time.how i wish titanic was not released on that year.

this film speaks of the truth about life -frustrations and triumphs.

title: Great coming of age movie
review:
Looking back ten years, this movie is even more meaningful because of the subsequent success of Matt Damon and Ben Affleck. They have become bona fide stars over the last decade. But it's impressive to think Matt and Ben actually WROTE this screenplay back when they were in college.

The movie itself is a true coming of age story for a unusual young man. However the unique of the character makes this movie. The story itself has reach characters that make the movie fun to watch and see what unfolds.

This is a light hearted, feel good movie that anyone can watch and enjoy. If you have never seen it, rent it today and enjoy.

title: good friends
review: I really enjoyed the originality of this film when it first came out. I liked they idea of a boy genius from Boston, Go RED SOX! I think the story was interesting and worked really well. There were a lot of little nuances, like the Dunken Donuts coffee, and the interaction between the friends that made this film great. Ben Afflec and Matt Damon had great chemistry; maybe it is because they were such close friends in real life. All the acting was really great. The accents were priceless. I'm glad that Robin Williams was finally able to get an Oscar because he is really great actor and he totally deserved it. This film made me wish I was better at math, seems very lucrative. I think this film is great because all the people seem real and their lives aren't thrilling but you really feel for the characters. I found this movie extremely entertaining and I would recommend it to anyone.

title: Fairly predictable ending with over the top swearing
review:
Will Hunting is a troubled kid who happens to be a super-genius. The storyline is simple and easy to follow. The acting and character building of Will is excellent. The film looks very natural and I see no use of exaggerated special effects, which is unusual in today's day and age. The writers and directors really put an effort in attempting to tell a story. Unfortunately there are a couple things that bothered me.

First problem I have is with the language. I think this movie would still have gotten their message across if they toned down their use of the F-word. I don't have a problem with it being used sparingly and I can understand it fits a character like Will, but when you have a therapist/professor constantly using it, that's really going overboard. Unfortunately, that's the one thing I remember the most about GWH.

Second, the movie is boring and fairly predictable. They do develop characters fairly well, but the movie moves along very slowly. And worse, you could see the ending from a mile away. There is little suspense throughout. How Will goes from a stubborn, hopeless kid to one that's willing to change his life around is sort of lame. He stumbles upon two of his mentors bickering, shows remorse, gets a tongue lashing from one of his mentors (Maguire), gives in, and all of a sudden he's a changed man.

My rating: 6.5 of 10

title: Very interesting and attractive plot
review:
This is a movie basically for everyone to understand... Specially for teenagers. Al the dirty language isn't something we don't hear everyday... And is not like younger people don't know how boys that age act.

I believe this movie to be a very good one, I was amazed when I saw that it was wrote by Matt Damon and Ben Afleck...

Robbin Williams was definitely a star here... He's very talented and it's really nice to watch him playing a role like that of Sean Maguire. I was truly amused by his last line... for more info, read the trivia section on this movie.

Absolute fascinating! 9/10

title: Great film hunting
review:
Good Will Hunting gets a 10 out of 10. Very powerful and emotional film.

This was a great film for me , it touches you in so many ways and was done very , very well . Matt Damon is great as the naive , but honest and brilliant man who's a genius, with his own terms borne of an abusive upbringing .This movie hits you on multiple levels , injustice , truth , death , love , corruption , abusiveness . I can't say enough about it , I watched this movie in the theater and wept, it held me throughout .Mimi is brilliant as the student who gets to understand him. I was thoroughly entertained by this movie and I recommend it highly if you want to be hit where you live , or where i live , or where we live , yeah where we live . SEE IT !

title: a journey through the human self
review:
THIS COMMENT MAY CONTAIN SPOILERS

i was surprised when i knew that it was Matt Damon and Ben Afflick who wrote this deep movie especially when discovering that Matt was just 27 and Ben 25 at that time. how were they able to dissect the human psyche in this brilliant, subtle way at such an age? Will Hunting is a psychologically disturbed guy who has been severely abused during his childhood and thus decides to take a defensive, aggressive approach towards every body outside the small circle of his closest friends. Will is a real genius in science yet his sense of loneliness, fear and emotional deprivation doesn't allow him to make use of this heavenly gift. he repels people out fear of going through more sufferings, of discovering that they are not up to his expectations, of being stabbed or deserted by somebody he becomes attached to. Will translates his anger into a series of hostile acts which reflect an unconscious desire of revenge against those who tortured him as a kid.

yet things seem to take a different course when professor Gerald Lambeau discovers Will's brilliance and decides to put him on the road of fame and success, an attempt the boy strongly resists because he doesn't have the will, stability, and strength that help him choose the route he wants to follow.

through psychological therapy sessions which Gerald arranges for Will, (Sean) the shrink succeeds in uncovering Will's old, untreated wounds giving him the courage to derive his judgments out of real experience noting that "nobody is perfect". Sean gained Will's confidence through open-heart talks away from the traditional patient-doctor relation. i felt some similarity between both characters, i don't know why. may be because both of them suffered in childhood or because Sean was satisfied with doing what he wanted to do, regardless of what others think of him, and tries to help Will reach the same satisfaction. may be Sean is not as famous as Gerald but he is in peace with himself.

i liked the part when Will asks Sean "didn't u think of remarrying ?" "My wife is dead," Sean keeps repeating- it is an emphasis of that idea of a "soulmate".

i liked Ben Afflick's part as Will's true friend. he urges him to go and pursue his career though they may never meet again. Afflick feels that Will he is a different guy,he has got a talent that should not be wasted in trivialities. in brief,he is a true friend.

the acting in this movie was superb Damon, Williams were the most shining stars yet the whole cast was great. two scenes i liked most: firstly,when Sean takes Will to sit by a lake and starts talking to him about the importance of going through experience. secondly. the climax scene when Will bursts into tears in Seans arms, it a moment of catharsis and relief.

the movie is a search for one's true self and a quest for man's ability to overcome his past sufferings and look forward for a new tomorrow.

title: Overuse of F-Word Kills A Good Film
review:
There are some excellent moments in Good Will Hunting. Matt Damon, the genius, conceited, janitor working nights at MIT, doing the bars, and eying the women with his (real life) buddy and best friend Ben Affleck along with the Psychiatrist, Robin Williams, who tries to keep Damon out of jail and on the straight and narrow path.

It's a very good coming of age character study, mixed in with some powerful scenic changes and moods. Director Gus Van Sant creates a genuine feeling for the characters and their situations so that you can (almost) feel empathy for Will Hunting and his troubled past. BUT...

The film's tender moments are ruined to the point of destruction with the F-bomb coming out of Damon's mouth at every other breath. This approach seems to be more for shock value, and it is overdone so much that friends of mine who had seen this movie thought it was overkill as well. A couple of relatives walked out of the theater because the language became so bad it was like, "OK, when is it going to stop?" The movie becomes a chore, a task to sit through when it shouldn't be because of the non-stop profanity. Many will think Damon doesn't need therapeutic guidance, but his mouth washed out with soap instead.

This is a movie where I actually like the censored TV print better! Without the F-bombs, the story is so much better and delivers a richer meaning than leaving them in.

The bad language really hurts what could have been a GREAT movie.

title: excellent writing, great acting all around awesome movie
review: Not only are Matt Damon and Ben Affleck great actors they're great writers. The writing for the movie was brilliant, it kept my mind wondering what was going to happen next the whole time. Robin Willimas gave one of his best performances yet. I feel as if Matt Damon was not acting but mearly having his everyday life taped for us to see, that is is how convincing he was in playing the part of math pridgy Will Hunting. To those that have not seen Good Will Hunting, I suggest that you see it as soon as humanly possible. If you like a great stroy, with actors he give an even better performance, Good Will Hunting was made just for you.

title: how ya like them apples!!!
review: I first watched this film on DVD after recognizing the title at the local video store. I was pleasantly moved. it is now one of my favorite movies. as i am sure many others were, i was shocked and initially a little doubtful upon hearing that the screenplay was written by Damon and Affleck, and couldn't help thinking that perhaps the latter's input was the occasional pizza run and neck massage for Matt's writers block. i am not a Ben affleck fan and use his name in the credits as a sign to steer clear but he doesn't manage to cripple the subtle magnificence of this picture. will hunting is a gem of a character, complex and heavily guarded, possessing a unique and superior gift and masking it with an arrogant mistrust in anyone but his four drinking buddies. robin Williams gives what i rate as his best cinematic performance as the only outsider to break through will's defenses and have any influence on his actions, using his own experience and surrendering his own covers to eventually gain wills trust and, in a poignant scene, releases will's true emotions and gives him the confidence to let himself do something with his gift. The effect that will has on every person he meets is relentlessly entertaining, whether it be the Harvard business student, the shrinks (and hypnotist), the other mathematicians, the job interviewers or Skylar. His un-rivaled knowledge and accompanying wit shape some hilarious and impressive scenes. when reading through the comments made about GWH i cant help but laugh while feeling sorry for those people giving one star and advising people to "avoid the hype". there are even a few people complaining about the language used. uuuuum, do you expect a person of will's background and lifestyle to speak in perfect English, avoiding profanities as to please those around him? the essence of the film is the character of will and his struggle to transcend the injustices of his upbringing. have the people making these comments any knowledge of movie history or prestige? the greatest movies made throughout history are those that step outside the boundaries and portray REALITY or a dramatized or sensationalized version of it. thats the beauty of cinema, we see the poignant moments of life portrayed in new and thought provoking ways. i advise anyone complaining over the language used to watch the likes of "a clockwork orange"; "goodfellas" ;or "shindlers list". these are great movies, high up on IMDb's top 250. i am not saying that GWH breaks any new ground in terms of explicit viewing because it doesn't; the language fits appropriately and any attempt to dull it down would ruin the essence of this masterpiece. I wont compare this movie to the heavyweights of cinematic history, because it doesn't need to be, GWH simply is a picture that must be seen, and WILL always be treasured by movie fans, it moves you in a way not many things can in the times we live in. The hype is just. "ordinary people" gave a similar message, but Good Will Hunting delivers it in astounding and unforgettable fashion. this movie is what superlatives were invented for.

title: A movie about a troubled young man, his past, and his future.
review: This film follows the life of Will Hunting, a diamond-in-the rough genius who makes a living out of the small town Southie by working as a janitor at the prestigious MIT. After anonymously completing an equation that eventually underlines his genius, he is found out by the renown Fields medal winner Professor Lambeau. With his help, along with a psychiatrist named Sean Maguire, he learns to accept his past and move forward with his childhood problems, despite his greatest fears, witty quips, girl problems, and bad habits, that are all the more amplified by his genius and lack of willingness to take advantage of opportunities.

title: Despite one or two flaws, worth watching for some excellent performances and a fairly original story
review:
Having been meaning to see this film for a long time I finally managed to last week and was largely impressed.

The film is very entertaining and has many memorable scenes of great acting and writing that are some of the best out there. I don't want to get into the plot other than say it is fairly plausible and original, borrowing from other genres but never feeling like its something we've seen before.

First of all, I'll talk about the films most impressive aspects. The best thing about this film by far is Robin Williams. I haven't seen too much of his dramatic work but his performance here is certainly the best I've seen him give and was definitely deserving of his Oscar. He wonderfully delivers some of the best emotional scenes in the film and is brilliant in virtually every scene he's in. Similarly, Minnie Driver is impressive as Will's girlfriend and brings a lot of welcome humour and credibility to her role and, along with Williams, keeps the film mature and not too immature- something I'll talk about soon. Similarly, Stellan Skarsgard is solid as a mathematician both jealous and fascinated by Will's talents.

The other good thing about the film is many scenes in the film. Many of the scenes between Will and Sean are well written and their is a fascinating and compelling speech made by Damon towards the end of the film on his refusal to work for the government.

The always excellent Danny Elfman delivers a very good score also.

Unfortunately these good aspects are held back by the completely unnecessary amount of gratuitous swearing throughout and average performances of Damon and Ben Affleck. If profanity is done tastefully and humorously (as shown by Quentin Tarantino) or is said out of desperation then that can help the material work. Here it doesn't. I didn't keep count but this film has an unbelievable amount of bad language that added nothing to the story and just felt like it was being used to fill dead spots in a conversation.

Another problem is the character of Will. He is far too cocky, arrogant and foul-mouthed to evoke sympathy and I believe his character should have been altered to make him a little more likable. Similarly Damon (despite one or two decent emotional scenes) is not very impressive either. Then again, thats probably his characters fault. The most annoying aspect of the film is Ben Affleck's character who I actually got so annoyed with I felt as though his screen time should have been shortened by half. Like Damon's, his character is the complete opposite to the one he plays in Armageddon and is largely unlikable and unappealing given he acts so stupidly throughout. Affleck (again, despite one good scene towards the end) therefore is unable to bring likability to his role either.

However, thanks to an original and intriguing story, some excellent performances by Williams, Driver and Skarsgard, the film is well worth watching.

8/10

title: Perfect Screenplay, Wonderful Acting, A Truly Great Story!
review:
Matt Damon and Ben Afleck wrote the screenplay for "Good Will Hunting"; they got Oscars for it. For once, I totally agree with the Oscar-Granting Committee, or whatever it's called.

Stellan Skarsgard, Minnie Driver, Robin Williams and Afleck himself put in superb supporting roles. Good for Ben, subordinating himself to Matt that way; Matt was simply stunning in his lead role.

I lived for about 18 years in the Boston area. I loved the true-to-life setting it made for this film.

THIS IS, SIMPLY, A TRULY GREAT FILM! See it. Buy it. See it again and again...

title: Must See!
review: This is one of those perfect, all-around well made films. The script was so well written there was no drawn out segments used to bridge one part of the film to another. The storyline flowed flawlessly. The cinematography was clean and maintained dramatic tone without unnecessary effects. The actors performances were outstanding Robin Williams is both believable and sympathetic in his role as a good-hearted psychologist with a sensitive past. He earned every inch of that Oscar. Matt Damon also gave a brilliant performance as the damaged genius whose quick comments and fast thinking has the audience laughing when they least expect it. The math professor was a scene stealer and it's a wonder why he hasn't appeared in more known films.

title: What 'education' really means
review:
Other reviewers, professional and public alike, have praised this movie to the skies for its superb writing, fine acting, and smooth direction. This was, of course, the career-maker for two of Hollywood's biggest stars, and an inspiration to young would-be filmmakers.

One element that has not, perhaps, received as much attention is the degree to which this movie deconstructs for the audience one of its primary tropes: what it means to be educated. As an educator, I find the point a crucial one, and one which elevates this movie from the merely "very good" to the level of "important."

There is certainly a simple surface reading, in several scenes in which the audience is explicitly told that it is individual talent, ambition, and personal character which make for genius, not just a collection of degrees after your name from a prestigious university. The best of these is the scene early on at the bar, as Matt Damon's "Will Hunting" character dresses down one preppie pseudo-intellectual after another, revealing that the 'education' they have received could have been bettered at any local library. It's funny, and it's true: education doesn't happen when you get an "A" in a class, it happens when you internalize a bit of knowledge so thoroughly that you can integrate it, on the fly, with other material, as Hunting proceeds to do in a blistering (and hilarious) verbal assault.

But just as important is the subtext of Damon's character's story-arc as he proceeds from working-Joe to star-pupil. Rather than being seduced by the prospect of grants, lab-space, or prestigious employment which his degree could net him, Hunting chooses to pursue his principles (and the love of his life). It could be a ham-handed, overly dramatic feel-good moment, but it's not because Hunting doesn't arrive at this decision by giving up his brains and following his heart. Quite the opposite. His decision is almost cold-bloodedly rational. It is arrived at after much debate, external and internal, and a number of quotes, statistics, anecdotes and analogies are forwarded from both sides of the debate: it's an instance of education in action, not as a bloodless, disconnected ivory-tower theory, but as a living model for our lives. Would that more students would approach their educations in that fashion.

title: Good Will Humping (Damn...Hunting) Is GOOOOD.
review:
You gotta like this if you like meaningful movies.

The plot is kind of very "Hollywoddish" come to think about it. "the mathematical genius + redneck from Boston gets fixed by the ultra cool looks like a failure but actually a winner shrink". now the beauty of the movie is that they acted and directed this plot out in a very believable way. I mean this plot and storyline could have easily been killed if it was done by some other people. Hats off to the cast, the director, and the writers(who r also part of the cast).

Matt Damone and Robin williams acted "Real". THats a very important factor . And the girl, well if she ain't British then she sure can act! The chemistry was awesome between matt damone and the girl(sorry don know her name).

Only reason, the only reason why I did'nt give the movie a 10 was that I felt that the storytelling lacked direction at times. everything else was just as close to perfection as it can be. The ending made me say "wow".

Don't see this movie if you are expecting a typical Hollywood "weeeee look what we have found. A genius from the gutters. Well show you the cool transformations in his life". See this for some amazing acting (esp by matt damone and robin williams), some truly awesome dialogs and a very cool ending.

title: One must be pretty sharp to think about this movie.
review:
Slight Spoiler!

I was really impressed when I saw this for the first time, and out of all of the actors, I focused my attention on Robin Williams. Usually an actor in works of comedy, his role in this movie was serious. Never had I seen such fine acting on Robin's part. This movie really defines his ability as an actor.

This movie requires one to think pretty quickly, as you can miss a lot of the detail as you head into the movie. This kid, who plays as a janitor has the mind of a math genius, however, he has a troublesome life. Robin's character eventually shows him the path that he should follow to make his life better, and put his "gift" to use.

I rate this very highly. It's an excellent movie. Not entirely family-friendly, but the adults and teenagers both might have something to appreciate.

title: Try to understand this ... please?
review:
1- It's a movie, you don't believe the plot lines? Welcome to Hollywood. For example: Do you think 8 guys would cross Europe & find Private Ryan? Of course not, but you've got to buy the basic premise folks. ANYTHING can and does happen IRL, why not this? (who cares if it is a Math Genius or a Stud athlete - hell both are rare, but how many 'sports stud' movie characters do we automatically accept?)

2- The REAL story within the story is not about the boy-girl relationship, or the buddy relationships. It is a man who finally realizes that another man knows what he's been through, GETS IT, and at the same time, has shown him that whining about it is not the solution. Robin William's character stands up to Damon's character in a way that nobody else ever has - and it works! Especially his "I'll end you..." line. (I was sitting in my seat thinking, "Robin Williams might kill me") I'm sure he'd never been made to believe that somebody would represent anything to him that strongly. THIS is the relationship in the movie that matters. Whether he makes it w/the girl or his buddies die by age 30 really is secondary.

3- Real life, sadly, involves less than perfect people who use less than perfect language. Sad, but true. Yeah, it was a bit much, but that's what Hollywood does. More people are jerks than are NOT jerks. They brought you down, and they brought Damon's character down, just like real life. So the point was made.

Bottom line? Enjoy it for what it is. A well told coming-of-age 'hope for the best in an imperfect world where you have both incredible strengths and weaknesses' kind of story. It is not a flawless story (name ONE?), but it made you care about some of the folks in it, which is more than most movies do. There ya go!

title: Daemon is a genius, Williams is the man who tries to tell him that
review:
Unless you wanna talk about you, who you are! Then I'm fascinated... I'm in! But you don't wanna do that do you? You are terrified what you might see...

Daemon is a genius, Williams is the man who tries to tell him that. We see a boy become a man, twice actually. The film is about friendship, love, passion, following your dreams. It is soft yes, it is American indeed, but no film have ever done it like that to me. This film is real, the acting is marvelous, I believe in it, I want to believe that Will is alive, that Sean is a shrink, and that Skylar is devastated in love with this weird man/boy who does not know who he is.

I love this film, nothing more to say :-)

title: Best motion picture!!!!!! Of every year
review:
Hi, i am Sam Radseresht. When i first saw this movie, i thought it was the film with the most bad language in the universe. But then, i looked at it again and again. And in the end, it practically became an obsession. I admired Robin's character Sean so much that i even wanted to be a therapist. I put books all over my room, read them, and studied hard in school. The film was truly a strong inspiration to my life, and i do want to take the opportunity to thank Robin Williams, for making his character so believable and real. Matt Damon and Ben Affleck for writing their wonderful screenplay that consisted of so many beautiful words of knowledge. Gus van Sant for making it possible and my mum for buying it a our local Virgin. So, if you wan't a movie of speech, excitement and emotion, Godd Will Hunting is the best so far. Even if you may not be a fan of Matt, Ben, Robin or any other cast members, please do watch it for they certainly deserve a big applaud.

It is one of those movies that will catch and touch your heart. A sea of Emotion. And in the end, there is a message for us all, but that is for you to find out. It focuses on Will Hunting (Damon) and how his troublesome past has left him isolated and off his path. When he is mopping the floors of MIT tech (boston), a teacher recognizes his astonishing talent and works with his math studies. Problem is, Will does not want that, and the Maths teacher cant understand his problem. So, Sean Maguire (Robin Williams) teaches Will to not be afraid, and realize to not waste his talent but use it. Together, they discover their resolutions and reveal their secrets.

But what strikes me about this movie is everything. If i was to find one word to describe watching this movie,,,..... Impossible. It just takes quite a lot to describe it. When i watched it, there was one scene that was so emotional, i could feel goosebumps on my skin and water in my eyes. A heartening experience, powerful and remarkable acting. SEE IT NOW. IT IS MORE THAN A FILM!!!!!!

title: To: Critics
review: There was an individual who talked about the unbelievability of this Movie, how Will was a math prodigy with only little formal education. He also said it isn't logical because he himself was a math God, and he would know. Well, to you, get over yourself, the movie was great! Go bowling With Professor Lambeau and have a nice conversation about "exciting math theory." I think it is definitely believable, hence the word PRODIGY. Some people don't like the fact that they aren't the smartest human being in the world. This upsets them, so they must claim "fallacy" to make themselves feel better. Yeah, Hollywood exaggerates, get used to it. Anyway, this movie is definitely a must see for anyone that can enjoy a movie without getting offended that there actually might be a genius in the world, and who can enjoy a beautifully made Film!

title: I Love This Movie
review:
I Can't say much about why I Love this movie so much because I don't know why I love it as much as I do. It is Addictive. It is Very Well Written. I just love this movie so much.

AN ABSOLUTE MUST SEE!!!!!!!

10 stars!!!!

100% BRILLIANT!!!!

WATCH THIS MOVIE!!!!!!!!!!!

ROBIN WILLIAMS IS SO GREAT AS A SERIOUSE ACTOR...TRUST ME.

This is an absolutely brilliant movie that must not be missed by anyone. see good will hunting... trust me it is great.

title: A Story Showing that the Best Special Effect is Real Human Emotion
review: When I first saw Good Will Hunting, I thought it was a remarkable movie. It instantly went to my top ten list. But "why is this movie so great?," you may ask. Well its the story about a mathematical genius who lives in a "safe world where no one challenges him." Every night he gets drunk with his buddies. One day he gets caught by the police for fighting and would have been sentenced to jail time, if it were not for an MIT professor who knows of his abilities and gets the judge to release. The conditions are that he must see a therapist and meet with Professor Lambough, the MIT professor, weekly to work on math studies. Will meets his match with a therapist (Robin Williams) and together they become friends and find solutions to life's hardest problems. A great movie, the best I've ever seen.

title: With A Stroke Of Good Will, Unknown Matt Damon Becomes A Star
review:
"Good Will Hunting" is a movie about a young man from the south side of Boston, the rough and tumble neighborhood of Southee, who is having tremendous difficulty coping in the adult world. He is reaching his twenty-first birthday and the age when he is no longer a ward of the state. The question is can he conquer his demons, grow into adulthood and be a contributing member of society.

Will Hunting (Matt Damon), an orphan approaching adulthood, has moved in and out of several foster homes as a child, and has had several run-ins with the law. But he is also a genius, who can solve math problems on the level of Euclid and Pythagorous. The only question is: In which direction will he turn? Will he stay with his street-wise gang of friends? Or will he grow up, start looking for a career job, and start taking some responsibility for his own predicament? Will Hunting is cocky, belligerent, and downright nasty at times until he finally meets his match with Dr. Sean McGuire, (Robin Williams). McGuire talks Will's language, sports, sex, and even profanity to try to get inside the boy's head, to see what's really bothering him.

Comic relief plays a large part in the movie. In one scene, Will accuses his first therapist of being gay and making a pass at him, sexually. Also at a local bar, Will is trying to protect a friend from getting humiliated, and gets into an argument about colonial imperialism with a smart aleck. This bar scene is also very enlightening.

"Good Will Hunting" is the movie that made Matt Damon a star. Matt Damon, along with good friend Ben Affleck won an Oscar for Best Original Screenplay. Robin Williams won an Oscar for Best Supporting Actor.

title: Very Good Will Hunting
review: This movie is wonderful just because it is all genuine human emotion. How it is natural for anyone, no matter how bright they are, to not want to experience life because of their own field of experience. How we can cripple ourselves with our own sadness. We see Will Hunting who has this amazing gift for mathematics, yet he does not use it. I think it is very poignant to show how on the surface, it appears that will does not use his gifts, or try to accomplish anything outside of being a janitor because he is stubborn. When the movie progresses, we see that he is not stubborn, just in a great deal of pain. The movie as a whole is great because of the chemistry between Damon and Williams. Being a psychologist, Sean Maguire(Williams)is supposed to unravel the enigma that is Will Hunting(Damon). To find out why someone with such exceptional abilities is constantly in jail. Sean attempts to guide Will. He does not show much companionship towards Will early on. Sean would not allow Will to toy with him as he toyed with numerous other psychologists. What I love about this movie the most is the fact that Sean was only able to reach Will and help him, is because Will first reached him, and helped him. Sean was still grieving over the death of his wife. Grief that was preventing Sean teaching at MIT instead of teaching at a community college. Will encouraged him to move on. Will was grieving over the painful experiences of his childhood. Sean encouraged him by making him realize "It's not your fault." One of the best movies I've seen in a long time. Any film and any actor that can truly portray vulnerability, pain, and the will to do what is best for you, is a great film in my book.

title: Incredible but authentic
review: This is the incredible story of Will a working class young boy who besides working as a janitor first and in the building construction afterwards, is also a genius in mathematics and several other scientific fields which he learned all by himself. But simultaneously he is a petty delinquent for which he has already got a criminal record mainly for assaulting other people in street fights with the likes of him. Despite being a real genius he is also an insecure boy fearing life and love due to the very unhappy childhood he had, which makes it very hard that he can take advantage of his intellectual ability. It also leads him to be rude to those who want to help him since he doesn't trust anybody. All through the movie we see the work of the two men who try to bring him to life and to take conscience of his own value: a maths professor and above all a psychiatrist who had his own problems in life too. This is shown in a brilliant way in terms of players' performances, images and dialogues with deep analysis of feelings and behaviours. All the players are excellent. A special reference to Minnie Driver as the boy's girlfriend with her spiritual and intelligent look and her moving reactions to some of Will's difficult to understand attitudes. This story is genuine indeed in terms of sentiments and actions and very well put on film. One of the best movies of its year.

title: Under-rated music
review: This is an excellent film for reasons mentioned elsewhere, but what I would like to add is a comment about the wonderful music that accompanies the film. The songs are written by Elliott Smith, who was truly an under-rated song-writer. I would urge everyone who enjoyed this film to go out and buy his album Either/Or, you will not regret it. His softly sung love songs add perfectly to the overall feel of the film. Elliott Smith subsequently played a song from the film at the Oscars ceremony, a somewhat bizarre scenario as he was a quiet and reserved man, somewhat out of place in that environment. Tragically he died in 2003, but his music lives on as an inspiration.

title: Robin Williams' best performance?
review: One of my all time favourite films, 'Good Will Hunting' portrays the trials and tribulations of a 20-something genius fighting to reconcile his talent and his lifestyle. Matt Damon is superb as the fresh-faced, insecure Will Hunting, and displays a striking sense of vulnerability beneath a rough, uncompromising exterior, particularly in the psychiatry scenes...which brings me to Robin Williams. Whilst I have occasionally thought that Williams can tend towards the cloyingly sentimental, his performance here as Will's psychiatrist is truly towering, which was acknowledged by a 'best supporting' Oscar. Peter Sasgaard (think that's how you spell it!) is also worth a mention, with an excellent performance an unlikable, but ultimately well-intentioned professor. Minnie Driver also stars in a nicely portrayed, if somewhat limited role.

title: A reflection of life..
review: Well..Much has been said and written about this fabulous movie..but the fact that every single person can relate to the movie is its USP..Not every one can be an achiever in life..or possibly come close to being one..But every one yearns to be a achiever..This movie conveys the message that "Its all in your mind.."..How many of us have scars engraved in our minds..It is up to the individual to get rid of these scars and try to achieve what he/she has set to out to do..This movie coveys this message to the core and that inspires me no end..Hats off to the director Gus Van Sant and Matt Damon & Ben Affleck for writing such an inspiring story..

title: Simply Genius Film
review:
Good Will Hunting is a beautiful and thoughtful film, which comprises the main aspects of brilliant film making. Director Gus Van Sant has taken the script and plot created by Matt Damon and Ben Affleck and created a world in which the film seems real. The film is strikingly naturalistic, which blends well with the fact that Will Hunting is such a genius. The relationships that Will Hunting finds himself in throughout the film are portrayed in honest and fantastic ways, showing the diversity of the character and the way in which he interacts with the people trying to help him in his life.

His genius is undeniable, but his person is generally flawed. He is charming in the most unnaproachable way...his world is made up of loyalty to his close friends. It is a safe world that keeps his immense intelligence out of the limelight, he is just one of them.

Matt Damon is brilliant as Will Hunting, as he illustrates the emotions of the character so vividly, you feel as if you go on Will's journey with him. His ability to write co-write the script also writes volumes for his artistic intelligence. His performance is helped by the truly excellent Robin Williams, who gives a performance on a par with One Hour Photo, or Good Morning Vietnam. He is immensely believable, the park bench scene is one of the most raw and touching scenes in recent cinema, and the background of the character is identifiable and a constant source of interest.

The support of Minnie Driver is classy and fulfilling, as there blossoming relationship is so believable. And co-writer Ben Affleck is superb, in his only acting role of merit, as Will's best friend.

The Oscars were well deserved for this excellent and beautiful film, any argument that champions this as an American dream style film or a corny coming-of-age love story, has missed the point of the film. It is about potential, redemption, loyalty and love. Truly brilliant film.

title: Damon + Williams + Math = Strangely, Brilliance
review:
In case you haven't seen Good Will Hunting (it's OK...I hadn't seen it until 3 weeks ago), it tells the story of a poor Bostonian young man named Will, played by Matt Damon, who has had an incredibly turbulent life and whose social status prevents him from achieving something. Though Will is brilliant and should be attending a school like MIT, he mops its floors instead. After getting into some trouble with the law, a MIT professor who needs Will's help to solve a perplexing mathematical equation takes the young man under his wing and helps Will receive a lighter sentence, providing he goes to a therapist. After seeing many shrinks, Will finally meets with Sean, played by Robin Williams, who eventually guides and befriends the reluctant Will.

Good Will Hunting is by far one of the most intelligent, well written films I've seen in a long time and it's quite deserving of its Oscar for Best Original Screenplay. Moreover, Robin Williams shines as the psychologist who is struggling to battle his own feelings of loneliness and worthlessness after the passing of his wife, and Damon is incredible as the hard-edged genius at the core of the film. Minnie Driver is also very likable as Will's girlfriend who constantly tries to get him to open up without angering him in the process.

Unfortunately, Ben Affleck as Will's best friend Chuckie is downright annoying. He tries to steal each scene he's in by screaming in his thick Boston accent or by stepping on the lines of other actors, but he fails to be compelling or interesting. I think I actually groaned every time he appeared on the screen. Still, overall Good Will Hunting was a thoroughly enjoyable film.

title: Simply put, a masterpiece.
review:
This film easily ranks as one of my all time favorites. The script is brilliant, the performances are genuine and powerful. Actually, powerful is the best word to describe this film. After the first viewing, I felt an overwhelming aftertaste of euphoria. There are so many valuable life lessons you can glean from this tale of a "super smart" yet troubled young man (Matt Damon)who finds the complicated simple yet the fundamental aspects of social human interaction very difficult. Given the fact that Matt Damon also co-wrote the screenplay (while in his early 20's) with real life pal and co-star Ben Affleck is even more impressive. I consistently find myself shocked to hear that some have not yet experienced this gem. If you love movies, you must see this movie. I can't seem to stop singing it's praises even as it approaches the films ten year mark.

In short, if you haven't already seen this film, find some quiet time, rent it and savor one of the highlights of cinematic history.

title: just a great film... every time!
review:
This is one of those films, no matter how many time you watch it, it never goes dull.

To cut this short, when you watch it for the first time, make sure you are alone or with only other film freaks! Then watch it again with the deleted scenes added and then AGAIN! with commentary added.

The Bar scene is a winner, where we get to meet Miss Drivers character, Skylar. I have tried Will's chat up line myself, but with no joy!

Also, i heard that the Dog Track scene, mini Driver actually placed a bet on the dog that won the race in the film, hence a smile on camera that cant not be staged!

If you like (simple) but very real films you will love this first film by both Ben & Matt. Another Gus Van Sant masterpiece as well.

title: Good humor, good content, and good lines
review: I don't know how anyone could not appreciate this movie. It has some of the most inspiring lines about how to live life. There are so many people who are so concerned about success and making a lot of money and the image of success. People don't think about whether or not they are doing something they love to do. You wont see Ben Afleck this good in any other movie, and Robin Williams is outstanding. It is a movie. Not all characters are supposed to be perfect;as long as the themes of the movie are communicated and you leave the movie feeling a natural high (you probably will) then the director has done his job. This should be seen by everyone!

title: An inspiring piece of film...
review:
Every now and then you come across a movie that though including some classic clichés, still manages to stand out and really affect you. Somehow this movie achieves just that. One can think that there's nothing special about this move. That there's nothing more to it than beats the eye. Well I beg to differ.

I first saw it back in 2003 and was completely absorbed by it. Back then I even considered it one of my favourite movies of all time. I saw it again this morning however and have to admit that it's maybe a bit too convenient to like sometimes. The overall great plot has some flaws, but it's still a great movie. I wouldn't go so far as to call it my all-time-favourite, not even close, but I still think of it as ONE of MANY personal favourites.

One of the factors that make this such a great movie is that it includes top notch acting. Damon and Affleck are really great along with both Stellan Skarsgård and Robin Williams who put on tremendous acting, especially Williams. But alongside them I have to say that Minnie Driver as Skylar also brings something to the deal that is well worth appreciating. She has this natural charm to her, that is quite unique and adorable.

Except from the great and talented acting, I fell for the plot. It appealed to me. Inhere also lies some of the clichés, but I feel that they made it in such a way that they get away with it. I don't now how. Can't really put my finger on it. But it works. They pulled it off. I found myself drawn to the mix between drama and humour, and was mostly intrigued by the relationship that develops between Will (Damon) and his therapist (Williams).

There's something rather fascinating and inspiring about this film. I highly recommend it. I wish I somehow could capture the essence of the film and express it to you in a better way, but I guess you'll have to see it for yourselves. At least do that and make up your own opinion about it. It's worth that much. And even though you against all odds :-) should disagree with my judgment, I doubt that you'll find it so bad that you'd end up regretting you watched it.

title: Excellent Movie!
review: It makes you laugh and cry. Couldn't believe how powerful this movie is. Great acting, writing,, and directing. Terrific ending. Loved the music. They don't make movies like these anymore. Why? It comes from the heart that what makes this film so compelling. Movies today are cheaply written and made. They cater to the lowest common demoninator of people in our live lives not worthy of anything. See this movie and it will enlighten you. Definitely worth watching a second and third time. Highly recommend renting it on DVD. Good premise and storyline. The location was also excellent in Boston. See this film! It is a must-see and deserved all the Oscars.

title: Definitely worth watching again
review: They don't make these kinds of movies anymore. This one had a lot of heart and wasn't pretending to be 'cool'. I get so sick of Hollywood glamour in movies today. There's not enough heart and soul like 'Good Will'. We need more movies that talk about the human spirit instead of spitting on it. Hollywood has become a frat boy house where no one cares about where we're going in the human race. No one cares period. They just want to make money and have their little power struggles. What made this a non-Hollywood movie was the genuine feel of Matt Damon and Robin Williams - nothing glamorous, just real interaction. Definitely cried in the end like everyone else. Amazing movie that deserved the Oscars. Highly Recommend.

title: Wow, what a beautiful film!!!
review: I was amazed by this film. A story of a young man ,who has a brilliant mind, but finds it easier to use his fists in any situation. I was very engrossed by this film, especially when Damon, the main character and Williams, his psychiatrist have sessions together, discussing Hunting's painful past.The romance between Minnie Driver's character and Matt Damon's is very gentle, which helps the audience to relate t them as characters. The only thing I objected to was the amount of unnecessary use of swearing. Swearing is often used for dramatic impact and effect or to portray the society in which a film is set , but I found the fact that every other word was a swear word quite off putting and useless. Other than that I found the film enjoyable and humorous in just the right places. My favourite part is the scene with Williams and Damon where both men embrace and Damon's emotional barrier is cracked, allowing him to be liberated from his brutal past. Affleck's part is easily as important as Hunting's friend. Such sensitivity. What a beauty!!!!!!!!

title: good script hunting
review: Even though the film has been out a good few years, I only got round to watching this last night after many friends had bigged it up. To be honest I did enjoy the film, I thought the script was really good from damon and affleck and Williams performance was top notch and worthy of his Oscar. It was quite heart rendering. The fight scene on the baseball court was not very realistic, and even though Matt played the character of will being a disturbed and lonely young man very well, I didn't feel like he would be the person who could possibly scare anyone. I love the scene on the park bench and the conversation between Will and Shaun, and Shaun stating that just because he has read Oliver Twist it doesn't mean he understands what will has been through, excellent. Overall I really enjoyed the movie and was impressed.

title: Trust
review:
Finally I watched the long-awaiting movie. As what I expected, it did not disappoint me. Although a genius can have high IQ, high EQ can not be assured. Smart Will had serious mental problem. He could not make good use of his talent. On the contrary, he was abandoning his life. Even his friend Chuckie felt unhappy for that. What he said to Matt on the construction site just proved that their relationship was so deep. I was moved by it. I believe that it is satisfying if you have such a good friend.

In fact Sean also had his unsolvable problem. Due to Sean's patience, Will began to accept him. It was the trust between them that changed their lives. Honest communication made them can overcome their respective problem in the end. Without trust, I can not imagine what our lives will become in reality. No trust, no friend. If you want to own a real friend, trust is necessary.

Robin Williams deserved the academy award (the best supporting actor). Matt Damon was as good as his The Talented Mr.Ripley. Another similar excellent movie is Finding Forrester.

Although it is not a masterpiece, it is absolutely worth watching. 8/10

title: Excellent
review:
This Movie was one of the Few movies, with Robin Williams in, I have enjoyed also insomnia, One Hour Photo. Robin plays his character really well, and makes this film the success it was, from an actor which seems to me, Has done so many children movies, he comes across like the forever daft laugh a lot actor not to be taken seriously but it was a surprise when i saw him, now i like him. Minnie Driver looks sexy as hell playing Matt Damon's girlfriend, I'm a huge Matt Damon fan, and if you like him, you must own this. Matt Damon Of course is who the movie focuses on, and he proves how well he can play any part given to him, a boy cleaning the school floors is actually the most brightest lad, the school has. Ben Affleck plays will hunting's best friend. & there's abit in the end, which i really liked, between the Damon/Affleck characters which made the end enjoyable. Id Advise this movie for everybody to watch, you will enjoy it if you like a good drama. Written by both Matt Damon and Ben Affleck winning them both their first 2 Oscars. Proving how Talented Matt Damon & Ben Affleck truly are. You'll see a young boy, living life on the edge actually achieve a goal, & climbing through a lot of obstacles.

8/10

title: Good Will Hunting
review:
Good Will Hunting is the story of Will Hunting "Matt Damon" is a mathematical genius but is working as a janitor at a maths technical school, when he is discovered but due to criminal record is ordered to take therapy from Sean Maguire "Robin Williams" who attempts to control Will and help him lead his own life. Also stars Ben Affleck, Stellan Skarsgard, Minnie Driver, Casey Affleck and Cole Hauser.

Good Will Hunting is a very powerful film, If you get through all the swearing you begin to feel Will's pain as his life story is thrown out on the table. Strong acting, believable storyline and a very original story, Great cast not a weak role and there are very few films in this genre that can get that across to the audience, it's a film to make you laugh, cry and get angry.

Matt Damon gets better every time I see him, top film best of its kind.

title: My favorite movie ever!
review:
My favorite thing to look for in movies is the way the characters interact with each other. I think this film does an excellent job of exploring the intricacies of interpersonal relationships and what causes people to become the way that they are. I give this movie 2 thumbs up (if I had more thumbs, I would give them, too).

I learn something new about myself, about people, and about life in general every time I watch this movie. I know that most people are usually watch movies just for fun. But if you enjoy thought-provoking movies, movies that challenge and stimulate you intellectually, then this movie is for you. I think that we've all felt like Will at one point in our lives, and so then Will's journey (meaning the plot of the movie), in a way,remind us of our own journeys.

I can't even tell you how many times I've watched this movie. It never ceases to amaze me and teach me new things. And even though it's such a deep movie, there is so much humor mixed in that breaks the tension. I have a friend who is also very fond of this movie, and we are always quoting humorous lines to each other when we're joking around. We also quote some of the more serious lines from the movie when having discussions. There are just too many great things about this movie to describe!

title: I loved this movie
review: I absolutely loved this movie. It is on my top 10 of all time favorites. The screenplay is original. I'm tired of watching the same movies with different actors, different titles over and over again. This one was truly original. It was long but went by so fast. I have now watched it at least 5 times and still haven't tired of it. The acting was also superb. Matt Damon at his best, Robin Williams, Ben Affleck. Ben Affleck hasn't been able to match his ability since. I highly recommend you to watch this and don't get the people who said they don't get what all the hype is about. The storyline, humanity and unrealistic expectations echo real life. The pain that the characters feel is also so real.

title: Good but not anything special
review: The double ego of maths genius and waste of space scrapper has been done before, it is a cliché now. However, this film is done well. The comparison between will (matt Damon) and his psychiatrist (robin Williams) is intriguing and nicely put together. Mini Driver plays the girl will wants, who is an intellectual who can merge into a group of lads, as when she tells the oap's 50th anniversary present joke. She also has a mean laugh!!! Will is an interesting character and he portrays the idea that even though you may have a skill, its not worth using it if its going to make you unhappy. You should do what will make you happy in life, as long as it doesn't hurt other people. Id happily watch this film again, its a romantic comedy,tame type of film you have cravings for sometimes.

title: GWH as a case-study in saving a non-active "protagonist"
review:
I find GOOD WILL HUNTING immensely engaging throughout. And from the point of view of a writer analyzing the script, that's amazing -- because Will, the ostensible "protagonist", lacks two of the usual defining traits for that role: he is acted-upon far more than he acts, and he has no "story-goal".

Early on he solves the hallway problem, he picks the fight in the playground, rescues Chucky in the Harvard bar, and pursues Skylar. From there on he coasts, until the end when he makes his one and only life-bending decision in the movie: He leaves Boston to go see about a girl.

To those teaching story-craft, I suggest it's more useful pedagogically to hang the label "protagonist" not on Will, but on Sean, the therapist played by Robin Williams. Will is little more the protagonist than, say, the "Mona Lisa" would be in a caper movie depicting a bunch of guys trying either to steal or save that painting.

Sean does have an announced story-goal: Save the kid. And he acts-on Will until he, Sean, achieves that goal. (Sean also has a personal need, though it's one he's not aware of: He, like Will, has to be saved. This amounts to another story-goal the audience wants to see achieved, and again it's Sean's effort that achieves it: In the course of saving Will, he saves himself.) This view is of interest to more than academics. The practicing writer  and directors and dramaturgs -- should study just how it's pulled off  having a lead character who's essentially passive, and yet who holds and satisfies our attention throughout. GWH is a good case-study in how to break a craft-rule and survive.

GWH footnote: The "official" version of the screenplay published by Hyperion does not have a single scene, not one, that's identical to the movie as released.

title: there are not enough words to describe how great this film is
review: Matt Damon and Ben Affleck are an unbeatable writing team and have created a marvelous film here. It makes you think about your life and how you do the same thing everyday and hope one day that best friend of yours is not gonna answer the door because they finally decided to do something instead of staying in the same spot all your life. I personally am going through that right now. I picked up and moved on a whim January of last year. Thats why i can truly relate to matt damons character and to add to this brilliant movie formula you have robin williams. If you have not seen this movie or are anything like me you will definitely want to pick this up because after one time you will end up watching it over and over and over again as i do. This is definitely a good will movie worth hunting for.

title: Gifted and neglected son of impoverished Boston neighborhood is found by Love.
review:
Good Will Hunting, a story of the profoundly gifted Will Hunting will resonate with all who still hunt for good will in the world. Stunning performances by the headliners; Driver, Daimon, Affleck, Williams, and those by actors not so well-known, make this original story by Daimon and Affleck unforgettable and real. Set across the disparate social contexts of the intellectual elite of MIT University and the impoverished blue collar world of South Boston, this story reveals that love, once again, transcends all. And love is its subject; the courtship, delights and follies of lovers, the love shared between men, the love for the natural beauty and truth revealed in science and mathematics, the platonic love between teacher and student, parent and child, and the violence and perversity of love betrayed.

This academy award-winning "best original screenplay" had a solid and natural up-bringing. Daimon and Affleck grew up in the widely diverse cultural context in which the story is set and their penetrating view of this world brings it credibility and importance.

In what is perhaps an unlikely assemblage of scenes and dialog, this classic story of struggle in pursuit of love and meaning is delivered by the strength and brilliance of the performances. In the end, its value, as entertainment and as art, derives from the truth of human nature embedded in it.

title: terrific job from Matt Damon and Robin Williams
review:
After seeing the remake of Hitchcock's masterpiece 'Psycho' I didn't know if I would ever watch a Gus van Sant movie again. But at a rainy Thursday night there was nothing on TV except Good Will Hunting. Hearing some people say how good this movie was made me want to give it a chance. So I did. Thirst I must that the acting is pretty decent here, even Ben Affleck (who I normally can't stand) seems to know what he is doing here. Robin Williams gives a marvelous performance and so does Matt Damon. I already knew how talented Matt Damon was when I saw him in Rounders and the Bourne Identity, but I think this was his best performance I have seen so far. The dialogue of the movie is superbly written. Some of the sentences really make sense and go deep. The story isn't bad and the character development is also very good. The direction is fair enough although I didn't really pay attention to that. Maybe I even overlook the 'Psycho' remake incident. No not really!!!!!!

But still this movie is very good and I sure recommend it to anyone who enjoys a good movie once in a while. Grade 8/10.

title: Very Good Will
review:
The film that broke both Damon and Affleck in the big league was definitely one of my favourite films of the 90's.

I would return to this film to watch Robin Williams character alone, he is simply outstanding as the shrink trying to get in to Will's (Damon) head, in particular he delivers a speech to Will sitting on a park bench that enchanted and amazed me.

I like the idea of clever guys being made into hero's in films for a change rather than the burly action figures we see in the same types of movie year in year out.

It is interesting looking back to see the different directions that Affleck and Damon's careers have gone, maybe neither of them will ever beat this moment.

title: Excellent
review: This is one of my all time favorite movies, and I am an outstanding judge of what is great and what sucks. Both Matt Damon and Ben Affleck were very good. They were so at home with the roles I fell into the movie and there was not any point at which I said to myself "that was lame" which is what I spend about 80% of my waking hours doing, I think I may even do this in my dreams. Oh yes and a big shout out to Robin Williams who I generally dislike, he is also very good in this movie. I know one person that did not like this movie and she is a little off in general, nice person but her taste in movies is absurd. Some of my male friends think I'm a bit light in the loafers for trumpeting this picture to whomever will stand still and listen. Despite this I think this is one of the greatest pictures ever made.

title: the celebrated screenplay deserves all the hype
review:
It's great to see the film that propelled Matt Damon and Ben Affleck deep into the slime and bowels of Hollywood (and in Mr. Affleck's case, before banality and big budgets crept in). Here, the two are inadvertently amusing and prove that the celebrated screenplay deserves all the gloss despite occasional lurches into intellectual pretension.

Damon simply oozes with intelligence and you simply believe him, 'psychological issues' and all. American academia's nefarious exploitation of genius, corporate capitalist corruption, friendship, the hypocrisy of The Good Life, finding your own niche in the world- these are among the things grazed by and effortlessly woven into the dramatic flow of the story- which is ultimately "Good" Will Hunting's discovery of self and love. The terribly maudlin Robin Williams injects warmth and scruples, and the Elliott Smith music resonates with redemption.

title: great movie
review: this movie really captured the true meaning of life i think. not like other movies where the main character is tough and strong and can handle anything Matt Damon showed that every person (even a genius) doesn't know everything. i would definitely recommend it as a must see movie because it is sad, funny, and inspiring. its a true piece of work and the interaction between the characters is phenomenal. Robbin Williams also was an excellent actor in this movie. you could see he really cared for will. i think this is one of the most touching movies i have ever seen in my entire life. i just hope that Matt Damon will sometime in the future do another wonderful movie like this.

title: And it gave us Ben and Matt to boot
review:
I have seen this film 3 times, and find myself liking it more with each viewing. There is a lot going on throughout the story. It is a lot about growing up--a lot about finding the courage to better yourself, and accept who you are without listening to friends you love, but may be better without for a while. The Oscars that year must have been interesting---(is there any tape available for previous Oscar telecasts?). These two unknown children dominating the awards. It's just become a classic movie now.

I like the story and the message it gives. I'm not too familiar with film school teachings, but obviously, these two must've done something right. Perhaps, the film school should examine their curriculm, eh?

title: Good to watch, inspiring of sorts, but has loopholes
review:
There have been many stories and cases about someone being mistreated/ abused/ abandoned as child growing up to hate the world, hate everything around him, and being disillusioned. In this movie, the protagonist, Will (Matt Damon), with that kind of past, is a mathematical genius working as a janitor at MIT. A Field's medal winning professor at MIT recognizes his talent and takes it upon himself to nurture and nourish it.

There are some serious loopholes in the movie. First, Will, though totally self educated, is shown to be genius at anything he can lay his hands on-- from history, to law, to organic chemistry, to, of course Maths. And all this while fully self educated. Its far more difficult to believe when, in the movie, he is mostly shown hanging around with his no good friends, picking up fist fights, drinking, getting in crimes, etc. I can understand amazing talent, yes, but even for that talent to show off as well it did in his case, the mind needs to be free from all this distractions. I can't help wondering how, he, in spite of all this disturbing things currently going on his life, he manages to do that. This is rather unreal to me.

Historically, the geniuses talked about in the movie and compared to Will (Einstein, Ramanujan) both didn't come from broken or abandoned families. Yes, both were geniuses who started of doing something else and were recognized late as geniuses, yes -- but that was because of social or educational systems in which they grew up that didn't recognize or encourage their merit. They could put their minds fully in the scientific or mathematical problems they were working on.

There are more clichés -- like the bar scene. I have something similar at "Harvard" bars, yes, but what is shown in the movie is rather exaggerated. Then, when referring to Ramanujan, the Maths Prof signs of the dot on forehead to indicate Indian -- thats a silly and stupid! MIT (and boston area, that has the BHCC too) has always had a lot of Indian maths profs and students, and while that action might have been understandable in the middle of cowboy country where no one may have seen an Indian for real, its difficult to imagine someone who works with so many Indians to give such a stereotypical description.

Then, the Maths prof himself, and his apparent inability to understand the effect of Will's past. Most MIT profs I know are more sensible than that. The relations between the faculty and the folks grounds dept (where the latter is seen swearing at the prof after he leaves) is much better here, and there is much much less swearing than is seen in the movie!

Wonder what the Bunker Hill CC folks thought of the movie, since in a way, it pits MIT against BHCC.

Still, its a good watch, and personally -- I can relate to somethings in the movie!

title: A Gem
review:
This story about a tough orphan who is an absolute genius struck a familiar note for me because Hunting (Matt Damon) reminds me of my father. Born at the turn of the 20th Century, his mother died after his birth and his father became such a drunkard and tyrant that my father left home at age 11 and did not complete school. A roughneck, stevedore, prize fighter, lumberjack, gun slinger, cowboy and rodeo rider, he finally married at the beginning of the Great Depression at the age of 30 to society girl and concert pianist who gentled him down. After I was born he sought a more stable and safe occupation and became a carpenter. He took correspondence courses to complete his education eventually getting his degrees in civil and construction engineering,

I knew he was smart in mathematics but I didn't know how smart until I took a geometry class from a teacher that was a retired professor from the University of California. One day he gave the class an problem that had never been solved. I took the problem home and asked my father if he could help me with it. Within an hour he had solved it. My professor was amazed. He gave me two more unsolved problems and my father solved both. Like Hunting he was an absolute mathematics genius. Nothing more came of it.
