My father was a brilliant construction engineer and that was his calling.

So the movie had a tone of authenticity to it. It was a good story although at times it was a bit contrived. I am not a fan of Robin Williams but his performance in this movie by itself made it worth watching. If there was a negative it was Minnie Driver who was miscast. Because she is an ugly duckling, perhaps that is why she was chosen but her acting and her accent were atrocious and I had to knock off a couple of stars on its rating. Otherwise, it is well worth anyone's time to watch.

title: Definitely worth watching
review:
I've noticed that this movie has received some harsh criticism. First of all, if you watch the movie and pay any attention, you can see that the story does make sense, and the casting works (I don't think they ever mentioned anything about an Irish gang). Is the story believable? Maybe. But the writing is good enough that it can get you to think, which is important. Also, any movie that can get such strong feelings from viewers, good or bad, has made an important statement.

The acting, particularly Robin Williams, is definitely top notch. If Ben Affleck could find half that level of integrity again, he might have a new lease on his career. This was the movie that (in my eyes at least) really established Matt Damon as an actor that could hold a movie almost singlehanded. And, while I'm not often a big Minnie Driver fan, her stark contrast to Matt Damon's character definitely livened up the movie. I can never really tell if the Academy picks them right. But I do know that this was a good movie. It doesn't weigh you down with anything especially sappy or depressing. It just tries to tell a story.

title: My Favorite Drama
review: As a Christian I try my hardest not to watch movies that have no moral value. From the previews I was eager to see Good Will Hunting, however from word of mouth I heard that it was full of cussing and violence. Well the rumors got the best of me and tragically I did not see this wonderful movie until a little over a year ago. My friend Maggie told me I had to see it that she watched it on tv. Maggie being my best friend, I listened. I rented the movie and watched it. WOW! I have never been so impressed with a movie in all my movie watching life. (And I watch ALOT of movies.) This movie is the best written, best acted, best directed, and best depiction of real human emotion I've seen to date. Not only does it deal with actual problems that go deeper than "I'm in love with Bobby but he loves Barbra Anne!" but it also shows how a real human being would deal with these problems. Truthfully this is one of the greatest movies of all time, and honstly yes there is a considerable amount of cussing and there is some violence. Still I would recomend this flick to any one of my friends, Christian or not. Well there's my two cents, don't spend it all in one palce now.

title: not that great
review: I enjoyed this movie because I lived my whole life in Boston, not Southie but a different neighborhood.  I enjoyed seeing the scenery that I am familiar with.  Look, there is no way anyone who is a genius will work as a janitor.  There are people who are smart or have potential who are also very lazy.  But even the most brilliant people can't read books that fast or memorize everything.  Remember the bar scene where he embarrasses that Harvard kid?  The guy didn't look or act like a Harvard kid.  He looked more like an MIT student, a science geek.  Many Ivy Leaguers are liberal and would be friendly to a poor bum.  In real life, Harvard students protested so the low-wage workers at their school can get better pay.  Then Matt Damon's character knows every quote from a book in a battle of intelligence with the guy.  Give me a break!  It's possible that he would be smarter in many ways, but not with deep subjects.  It's only a movie though.

title: Choices
review: "Good Will Hunting" portrays a powerful struggle of a young man (Matt Damon) who is a math prodigy with decisions about life's lesson.  Trouble never seems to be far behind him when choices are steered in the wrong direction. No longer being of free will to make his own decisions, the only choice for Will is to be placed in a state penitentiary or to complete psychiatric therapy for his anger management issues. Determining a correct path in his life is not the only decision which Will must face as a young adult, but it can be one of the toughest.  While facing the judicial system, Will must make his anger work for him, not against him. This is a huge obstacle in maintaining friendships while trying to reinvent himself.  Will has the potential to become an elite mathematician, but instead uses his free will to experience his own road in life.  Although choice is a powerful tool, unless used to the fullest positive potential, it can possibly back-fire.  Decisions are faced everyday in each of our lives, but some of us take for granted the gift of decision and free will.  While being given a great gift one could consider Will as a man with potential, but no desire or initiative.  One might consider this the ultimate dilemma in life. The realistic `view of the working-class' is portrayed throughout the movie, providing a sense of belonging to the millions who fall in this category.  The setting was a bit predictable, which led watchers to feel the connectedness.  The dialogue might be appealing to a younger generation, who use vulgar words to express themselves, versus an older generation who find this repulsive.  All in all, I give this movie an A-.

title: A Masterpiece, one of my favourite movies of all time
review: Good Will Hunting, a breakthrough for actor Ben Affleck. In Good Will Hunting we see the cunning, snappy remarks made by all the lead actors Matt Damon, Robin Williams, Ben Affleck and Minnie Driver. This movie shows a good template for what every movie needs, good writing, acting, directing, and a well though title. If anyone deserves an award for memorizing dialouge it's Matt Damon spitting out that huge speech in the one job interview scene. Also this film is known for the winning of the two Oscars which were Best Original Screen Play and Best Supporting Actory which was Robin Williams, a well deserved award for that matter. Good Will Hunting recieves a perfect 10 for me.

title: How did I miss this fine film previously?
review:
I think the title turned me off, and with the cast, I thought it would be another teen film. This however kept me riveted as to how Will would turn out and how his mentors would handle him. Matt Damon and Ben Affleck have gained new respect from me for their fine story. Robin Williams was such a silly twit in so many roles, but he deserved his Academy Award as the understanding psychiatrist. As Will said to him, "I have never met a psychiatrist who talked so much."

I did not like Minnie Driver. She is very unattractive and even though they explained away her English accent as private schooling, this did not convince me. Even so, it is a fine film and the ending was just right!

title: An enriching cinema experience
review:
Will Hunting (Matt Damon) is an orphan who has been to a number of abusive foster homes. At twenty, he starts working at the prestigious MIT as a caretaker on parole, since he's been involved in several assaults. One day the tough maths question on the board is found solved and the searching of the mystery genius begins. When Professor Gerald Lambeau (Stellan Skarsgard) realises it is Will who has solved the difficult tasks, he decides to help him by offering him working on further maths studies and seeing a psychotherapist. Talented and yet highly defensive, Will manages to scare all the shrinks away and eventually Professor Lambeau has to turn to psychologist Sean Maguire (Robin Williams), his university roommate for help.

Sean's unique approach finally touches the deep inside of Will's complex and it gradually dilutes Will's insecurity and distrust of people. Meanwhile, Will falls in love with Harvard med student Skylar (Minnie Driver) but later has to confront his inner uncertainty. In the end, Sean and Will helps each other to deal with their own issues.

I simply do not comprehend why on earth some people out there don't appreciate this film, and I don't think I have to, because I know this is a GOOD film. The acting is intense and the dialogue is witty and often hard for the actors to carry out reading. The story is about a highly intelligent young man who has too many past injuries to heal and who eventually is given a helping hand (two, actually) to rediscover himself. The ending is just a clever one. 9.9/10

title: Good Movie, Williams does a great job.
review:
This is one of my favourite movies, in the same category as Kevin Smith's CHASING AMY. The story is great, backed up by a really great script.

Sometimes I can't believe that Matt Damon and Ben Affleck really wrote this screenplay because sometimes I think Kevin Smith wrote it but I could be wrong and may well be completely wrong.

title: Moving and inspiring (huge SPOILERS)
review: The dialogue in this movie is riveting because it gives you a feeling of a chess game of wits and rhetoric, set in modern times. I agree with others who've said that the movie's draw is that basically it's a well-written essay on the extent of the power of the intellect. Will Hunting at first seems like an omniscient god, but the question keeps coming up: so why is he a janitor? The answer is that no matter how much you know, you cannot go anywhere without trusting other people. You can't find love all by yourself; you have to have faith on someone to return it. Will's problem is similar to being rejected by girls over and over again: the hurt/pain tells you it's not worth it and fate will let you down anyway. Anyway Will thinks that by not trying to take his life anywhere, he's playing it safe. The thing is, he's right in that it is the safest, most controllable thing to do. He should see, however, that it is possible for people other than his childhood buddies to love him unconditionally. He refuses to see it, until Sean without asking or warning simply shows love. He didn't ask for it but he got it anyway. That is how you move a genius.

title: A mind-blowingly bad movie
review:
I tried to watch this on cable, but I kept getting annoyed and finally disgusted and turned it off. What a piece of tripe this is. I have no idea what the folks who rated it highly were smoking, but it is surely one of the worst movies I've seen in a long time.

The concept is insultingly bad. A kid working as a janitor solves a highly sophisticated math problem? And not just any old college, no. It has to be M.I.T. Yep, I'm sure that happens every so often. From this brilliant premise the movie goes rapidly downhill. Violence, ubiquitous cursing, infatuation with cigarette smoking, social ineptness - ah, the life of the troubled-yet-brilliant youth. How many movies like this have been made?

I found the acting to be smarmy. Cocky and irrelevant, just like the characters, the plot, the writing - the whole movie. It keeps trying to put on the Hollywood-haughty airs and tries to pass itself off as something special. In fact, there's no point at all. You don't care about the kid; he's just either too sharp or too weak, and he can slip between either of them. With all these fake antics you finally just give up even caring the slightest bit. Maybe these actors are talented to some extent, but that is all wasted.

It's one I'm glad I didn't waste my money seeing in the theaters. Don't believe the hype. It is one to avoid.

title: Flashdance with calculus
review: This showed up on TV last night, and I was interested to see a movie that had so much "buzz." It was very watchable, entertaining, but a movie wish-fulfilment fantasy   - hence the quip "Flashdance with calculus." I won't enumerate my quibbles here, nor the things I did like about the picture. Nonetheless, I did enjoy it, and I *do* like Minnie Driver.

title: for the cynics
review: some of you have taken great pleasure in pointing out the negative things in this film (e.g. will's arrogance, etc.)...but I think a positive look at the philosophy behind some of the ideas may just give us some practical advice to how "the good life" can be spent...my favorite scene is in the meeting room with robin williams and matt damon where they both harp on each other for using a "super-philosophy" for merely surviving through our self-protecting mode of existence. Robin Williams' excuse was that he had already played his cards and doesn't regret a minute of the time he spent with his wife despite the great pain he feels now. Matt Damon is in utter confusion, not knowing how to commit to anything in a serious manner; instead pushes everything out of his life as a defense mechanism.  It can be said that both use this super-philosophy to supress what could be a genuinely lively and thriving future, as a means to not love to the fullest potential. How can a person live life abundantly without ever putting themselves in a position which risk is involved? In my opinion its impossible. Is this what you gather from the "super-philosophy" scene? let me know what you think...

title: A brilliant script. A genius.
review:
The movie is a brilliant script that I hear Matt Damon wrote for a English class when he was in college.

Mysteriously I always missed the movie when it was on television, and it was played several times. I would watch just the start and miss the rest each time due to some or the other reason. Finally I watched it in whole now on 21st Nov 2003.

Will Hunting (Matt Damon) is a genius for whom most of mumbo-jumbo math and O-chem is "just a joke". He works as a janitor in MIT and solves a problem written on the board in the passage he mops. He is discovered by Prof. Gerry who gets him out of jail (assault charges) on two conditions 1) Will Hunting works with Prof. Gerry 2) He sees a therapist.

Will has a tough shell around him which he doesn't let anyone crack open and trespass. He is cocky, abusive and least bit considerate towards Prof. Gerry's attempts at polishing him into a Genius who can be of use than a Genius who just ends up being a construction worker all his life. Enter Robin Williams and the rest is for you to watch. Must watch.

Robin Williams plays his role so well that you forget you are watching a movie, you forget he is an actor and not a professor or a psychologist. This happens to me each time I watch a Robin Williams film. The sessions that Robin Williams and Matt Damon have are some of the best parts of the movie and the last session where Sean McGuire (Robin Williams) finally succeeds in opening up Will Hunting is the best scene of the movie.

The character of Will hunting seems to be complex but it is not really. Why would a genius not want to work for some big company or the US Defence and make millions or billions? Why does he just wanna be what he is? And it frustrates you as the viewer, while ur trying to find the key that would open him up. Ur frustrated waiting for him to stop being so arrogant, why the hell can't he be a bit 'nice' to these guys? Ur trying to be a detective, and trying to find the great reasons. And that is how the script brings a mild suspense and tension to itself, mild.

Minnie Driver, the English girl is an amazing actress. She is such a normal girl, who laughs loud and can still be gentle and she is very smart too, and vulnerable. U think why is Ben Affleck doing whatever he is doing in the movie. Ben Affleck answers this question brilliantly in a scene that works as a catalyst in the transformation of Will Hunting's character. Stellan Skarsgård (Prof. Gerald Lambeau) who takes up the challenge of refining the Gold ore that he mined shows great patience. One would really feel for him and his passion for math, especially if ur a lover of math.

This is one of the best stories and a very well sketched script. Go get a DVD.

title: Entertaining
review: I re-watched this movie the other night. I saw it when it came out and thought it was so-so. A bit predictable really, as people here have pointed out. But I also found it to be entertaining. I like Gus Van Zants films but I was surprised to learn that Matt Damon and Ben Affleck wrote this script. Good job!

title: Good for an American film
review:
I am thoroughly surprised that simpletons (so I thought) such as Matt Damon and Ben Afleck wrote this. The story is perhaps a little predictable, but I wouldn't call it cliché. It shows interesting character development and bonding, therapeutic techniques, and the windows and barriers of a genius.

Maybe I enjoyed this because I'm not a genius, and could somehow relate to the writing of two American rednecks.

Good movie. 7/10

title: An excellent feel good film...
review: This drama features great acting, storytelling, and direction.  Though the story may be somewhat familiar and predictable, the actors draw you into their lives and characters so that we care about what happens to them. This is an excellent feel-good film!...10/10.

title: Awesome Dialog
review:
Saw this for the second time last night. I liked it pretty good the first time, but liked it even more on the second viewing. Perhaps I was let down a little when I saw it the first time after all the hype? Anyway, on my second viewing, I really noticed the incredible dialog between Robin Williams and Matt Damon's character, most of which was delivered by Robin Williams. Superior stuff. Mr. Williams, you are far better at drama than comedy!!! In fact, it is so good, I really have a hard time believing that the same talent that produced Dogma wrote the dialog in this movie! I think there must have been some assistance on this part.

I even thought Affleck did a pretty good job in one place, which I missed the first time. At the end of the movie, when Ben's character goes by Matt's character's home to pick him up for work, and Matt is not there, you can actually see the light bulb come on ... very slowly ... while watching Ben. Well done.

Cool story. I don't know what it is referred to in a story, script, or screenplay, but I am noticing it more and more, and it occurs in this movie too. What I am referring to is when something is explained in one context earlier in the movie so that it is more fully understood later in the movie, usually for a very emotional purpose. In this movie, some of William's brilliantly rendered dialog concerns telling his buddies he has to "see about a girl" when meeting his future wife for the first time, instead of seeing game 6 of the World Series. This dialog is very emotional. So, later, when Matt uses the same line, all is understood with little said. Elegant. Same concept was used in Rock Star concerning "taking a pi$$". But, the best I have ever seen this done was on the last Cheers episode that Shelly Long was on when Dianne and Sam were saying goodbye. She supposedly was only leaving for a few months. He says "Have a good life." She explains that he says that as though they will never see each other again, which we know to be the reality as does Sam, though he won't admit it. She has explained the meaning of the phrase to us the viewer. She asserts, she will be back. After she is out of earshot, Sam says again "Have a good life" letting us know the finality of their relationship. One of the best pieces of dialog I have ever seen!

But, back to GWH, I think it is a very good movie, and well worth watching. Very impressive for them (Ben and Matt) to have done.

title: movie back to the basics of greatness
review: I viewed some of the previous reviews, where people seem to have a very off view of this movie, and that may be because of the big named actors in the film. I vote this movie as a 9, there is no justification to rate it at a 1. This film was not sent to be made because of damon and affleck, but is what made the famous to begin with. So please, thank the academy, and if you want to see a film with humor, drama, a bit of fighting, with a touch of love and friendship. See this film.

title: added facts about the movie
review: I am a full-time sculptor living and working from my studio in Stratford, Ontario, Canada. Over ten years ago I moved to Northern California where I met, at a gallery opening, the American Poet William Leach. We fell in glorious love and eventually moved through New Mexico, Iowa and to Canada where he died at age 45 years of age, 6 years after I met him, we were married in hospital one year before his death. While in California he told me the story of his life including a story about being a janitor and some of the 'events' that happened during that time, he also mentioned that later friends had spoken to him about the interest in making a movie about his life, which he had no interest in, in fact the chaos this would have caused in his very private and reclusive life as a poet. Later when we were living in Iowa a friend said we had to see a very wonderful movie about a 'genius janitor' and told us the basic story of the movie. We both were in shock! This was the movie, years later, about William's life at that time. He was never able to watch the movie although he tried, but tears would stream down his face, and when I finally asked him, gently why he cried, and why he could not watch the movie, besides seeing all his friends depicted and recalling that time of his life in such detail, he replied, "I had so much to offer and I was pushing a broom". And we never spoke of it again. I think it is important that people know at some point in history that the movie was based on a real person, a very amazing person of great personal strength, a beautiful person filled with love for the world he lived in, and such a gifted poet. He wrote 6 books of poetry, all remain unpublished, he received news of 7 poems to be published in Descant, in Canada, the day after his death. If anyone has any interest in contacting me to learn more about this man, a Renaissance of splender and joy, please contact me, he was the 'genius janitor' depicted in the movie, "Good Will Hunting", and his name was William Leach, poet. Thank you! Susan Murar.

title: Simplistic, Elitist Heartwarmer
review:
*Spoilers*

Every time I see this movie I can't help focusing on the elitist premise. I still love it, but it's getting harder and harder to get carried away with it.

Ever notice how everyone in this movie is either a violent, profane slobs or cultured elites? The two characters who seem to belie this (Will and Robin Willams) are really just fallen elites: Williams, one who wandered far from the ivory tower and ended up teaching at Bunker Hill Community College; and Will, one savaged by the blue collar world he was born into.

Indeed the point of this movie is to bring Will and Robin Williams back into the fold, because how could anyone actually finding teaching at a community college rewarding? Or construction and demolition? My Word, that is for the lower classes.

Perhaps by dint of their natural talents, Will and Robin Williams don't belong in the worlds of community college and construction. Fine, I could buy that, if the Affleck and Damon hadn't felt the need to paint those worlds with such a broad and unflattering brush. To show the Bunker Hill Students as slack-jawed fools the first we enter William's classroom. To have William's character leave pack up and leave the hopeless, intellectual black hole that is their screenplay's Bunker Hill CC. To have not one character outside the elite-working class polarity, like a middle class college grad (not from an elite college)? Minnie Driver's character was an opportunity to aerate this suffocating polarity, but Matt and Ben saddled her with a trust fund and med school.

Would it have been a tradegy if Will--after being counseled and helped by Williams--went back to southie? Or went back to his construction job? Is his working class life so utterly irredemable? In Damon and Affleck's simplistic, MIT-Harvard-Ivy-League-or-nothing world, yes. Will's genius is nothing if it cannot be utilized by the establishment. I mean look at the alternative! And his reward is a big-breasted, big brained English babe and all these companies he interviews with at toward the end are willing to pay him.

It's not surprizing that Affleck and Damon came from middle to working class backgrounds to write this. Indeed, the most rabid snobs are usually those from humble backgrounds who achieved vast success. And nothing aggrandizes that success more than showing the ignorance, sloth, and violence from which it escaped.

Anyway, I wish I could still enjoy this movie the way I did six years ago.

title: Wow!
review:
This movie can only be described in one word: Unbelievable. Following in the footsteps of Damon and Affleck, trying to make my own work instead of trying to find it, it truly amazes me how well and how hard those two worked over the years to put this movie on the screen. I think, that if Titanic hadn't come out in '97, that Good Will Hunting would've won best picture in a heartbeat, because, well it's hard to beat Titanic, anyway...

This movie goes down on my top ten list of greatest movies, and that ain't no easy acheivment. Yeah, my top ten list means nothing to yous guys, but maybe it will someday...

Good Will Hunting is one of the greatest movies I have ever seen. 10/10.

title: 10 out of 10
review:
Easily one of the best films ever made. Great story, great acting,

great. Matt Damon and Ben Affleck not only give amazing

performances, but show that they know how to write a very good

screenplay, I'm glad they won the Oscar in 97', they deserved it.

And of course Robin Williams shows that he can do anything. All in

all this movie is a work of art.

title: An authentic, moving, honest classic
review: This is one of the most genuine movies i've ever seen.  It's not perfect - on the contrary, it feels kind of rough.  But it's just a really honest movie.  You can tell it wasn't polluted by the big budget Hollywood mentality like so many movies nowadays are.  Although I'm skeptical that this movie really deserves a 10 from an artistic perspective, I don't regret my vote, because I think this movie is the embodiment of what moviemaking is all about.  It tells an incredible, human story in an honest, deep, and very enthralling fashion.  Also, I think the acting is just amazing, *especially* by Matt Damon, Robin Williams, and Minnie Driver.  I think it's great that Affleck and Damon wrote the script and followed through with getting it made...  Definitely a movie worth watching, for casual moviegoers and hardcore movie buffs alike.

title: Brilliant and inspiring
review:
Will Hunting (Matt Damon) is the janitor at the most prestigeous college in the country. He is also the most brilliant person there. He solves incredibly difficult equations in minutes, where it took others years to. He is well read in history, mathematics, and art. But spends his days drinking with his buddies. It is not until one of the professors (Stellan Skarsgard) discovers his genius, that his life starts to turn around for the better. But he also has alot of anger. As a part of Will's probation, he must see a shrink (Robin Williams). Will also meets a girl (Minnie Driver) that seems to be his soul mate. With the help of Sean the shrink and Will's best friend Chuckie (Ben Affleck), Will acknowledges his potential and his abandonment issues. This movie is very well written and acted. Most especially by Damon and Williams. It shows that even the most complex person can find solace and understanding in others, if he only opens up. The movie was nominated for 9 Academy awards, it was truly one of those special feel good movies that had a message. And has quickly become one of my favorite films.

RATING: **** out of ****

title: Good!!
review:
This is a sound satisfactory performance from all involved.

For first timers, Damon & Affleck do well but the real chemistry sizzles between a laid back Robin Williams & Damon. Williams returns acting to the old Hollywood style of gestures and emotive expressions and says a lot more with his eyes, demeanour and personality.

This is a defining moment for Williams who convincingly breaks from the slapstick comedy gamut to settle into a thoroughly serious role and gives the performance of a lifetime.

The scene where he breaks thru Damon's chaotic personality with the mesmerising but calming "It's not your fault, it's not your fault" just blew me away

I came away feeling enriched by the entire experience, with a lot of admiration for Affleck and Damon but with great respect for Robin Williams. He is indeed an actor's actor.

Good Will Hunting delivers soundly.

10/10 Overall!!!!!!!!

title: Brainless romance of brilliance-by-numbers
review:
The intellectual endeavour that is pure mathematics gets mopped-up, in this film, about as mechanically as the floors our janitor-hero swabs in the College where he works: He idly solves a conundrum left by a professor in order to test the ability of his undergraduate class to their limits.

Our hero can't take anything seriously, though, - least of all an ability that should command any number of excellent, albeit not necessarily academic, occupations - because of an abused childhood. He seems an unlikely combination of colossal arrogance and extremely low self-esteem. This does at least lead to a glorious put-down of some dim rich kid who is nerdily annoying a girl. This is easily the best scene in the movie. The pay-off, when he exhibits the trophy of her 'phone number to the bested contender, saying, 'How d'ye like them apples?' sets up a likeable, if difficult, underdog whom we really want to get to understand.

Unfortunately, this was the only good scene. The intriguing personality of a lad with enormous ability, but a wayward character born of social deprivation, and his anticipated moral struggle to control his mental endowments, is never developed. To put it another way, his character was

never properly conceived and identified in the first place, and so can never be shown developing out of the contradictions of his creator's original confusion.

Part of the problem is that the film half-wants to be another florid paean to the Romance of Learning, along the lines of 'Dead Poet Society'. The presence of Robin Williams - thinly-disguised under a pair of cartoon-shoulders that could only have come out of Popeye's spinach-tin - keeps reminding us of the inspiring teacher he was in that much more reflective (if imperfect) work. But the teacher in 'GWH' is a bland cipher. We shall see that this hopelessly scuppers the film.

In 'GWH' the acquisition of knowledge is presented consistently as being no more than a superior party-trick, the accidental product of a photographic memory. Or even as some virile clash of champions. We see this most absurdly in such scenes as that of the dismissal of the 'great mathematician', after he has been effortlessly bested in the solving of an even bigger and nastier mathematical conundrum, by our young turk: This obviously shattered individual reels off to recover from the mental devastation of being so utterly routed. Presumably he will end his days like some punch-drunk boxer, doing menial tasks, such as mopping the floor, perhaps, - now totally unfitted to draw his inflated salary as a star academic! Or this absurd shoot-out of ten-gallon brains might put us in mind of the baddy in some Wild West circus turn, humbled by the white-hatted radiance of the heroic cypher! There is certainly no inkling, here, of the collegiate pursuit of knowledge. There is no dawning engagement with the wider, grown-up world. There are no shadings. There is no reflection. There is not a particle of reality.

This is mere intellectual philistinism and immaturity. As bildungsromane, this film is the equivalent of the 'Rocky' fight stories. The character's development is told purely in all-American terms of adolescent virility - he is, and remains, a 'regular guy' who is true to the common experience of an intended audience of equally immature peers. His actions are authentically animal, at least, while, on the other hand, his thoughts are nothing more than pure automatism, bereft of the intellectual effort that would only pollute the blond beast so beloved of Americans, handicapped as they often seem to be by a profoundly insecure self-image. It is in order to reform, not his thinking - which is completely incidental to this drama - , but his social behaviour, that he is being granted the boon (as here it appears, rather than as the right!) of education. His therapy is political, intended to indoctrinate him into conformity with general social mores. It does nothing to render him a fit candidate for a higher degree.This alarming, if unconscious, exposure of this creepily conformist agenda, that is at the heart of America's bone-headed populism, is perhaps the only factor making this film worth consideration at all. As a source of sociological reflection on our great neighbour, it is quite alarming to observe herein how readily American youth appears to subscribe to its own enfeeblement.

What a devil's bargain is offered our Everyman of America: Self-realisation through Education - but only, and expressly, through the Trial of Therapy, that uniquely American tool of totalitarian thought-control. It is as if we are being given a re-make of 'A Clockwork Orange', in which we are unblinkingly asked to applaud the perversion of the unruly but human potential of Alex into the bland, neutered and utterly soulless citizen of a society of the like-mindless. This is what 'GWH' implies, by its deliberate confusion of education with therapy. Where 'Dead Poet' inspires (albeit in a rather 'Reader's Digest' fashion), 'GWH' prescribes. The pervading niceness that comes over our bright bad boy is every bit as creepy as 'Clockwork Orange''s brainwashing scenes - more so, since the picture seems blithely untroubled by this perversion of true, organic character development.

Even the more wayward knights of King Arthur's Round Table were expected to actually study discipline, and team-work, and to understand why they should submit to the judgement of their intellectual peers. Even the mad fantasist of Robin Williams' 'Dosser King', in Terry Gilliam's Arthurian subversion of all-American values, demands submission to his testing discipline only in order to restore Jeff Bridges' character, whole, to himself. Nowhere in the juvenile film at issue is the getting of wisdom represented as what it must be, even for the brightest students: 1% inspiration, and 99% perspiration. But the American way - the Hollywood way, at least, - to self-realisation is to overdose on emotionalism, as apparently only pure sensation can lead Americans to the true goal of all human fulfillment. Mathematics is not even a witty McGuffin in such a childish formula. And the sprinkling of other cultural references provides no more than high-toned decoration - an impatient short-hand for the engagement with serious and difficult cultural issues, which are entirely absent from the pretentious, adolescent, Ed Wood-scale of artistic self-delusion on display.

Hence the spreading soft-focus of the film, after the first few establishing scenes, and the increasing redundancy of a plot that was never honestly posited on intellectual endeavour at all.

So: Just another Hollywood fairy-tale, without any of that haunted, grown-up sense of darkness that makes a film like Kubrick's 'A Clockwork Orange' such a powerful fable of the human soul.

A superficial, brainless teen romance of brilliance-by-numbers.

title: A great amount of respect for this simple, yet profound work
review: Matt Damon and Ben Affleck deserve a lot of credit for this movie.  One reason they painted such an excellent portrayal of life as it really is or could be, may be attributed to their youth.  Youth facilitated this film with universal themes of the transformation from youth to adult, and to balance the rebelling nature of Will Hunting, Robin Williams adds (with a very well developed character) the humbled but wiser soul of an older man. Even though Will being so naturally gifted at math seems a little out of the ordinary, it is supposed to be this way. The movie takes this abnormality and uses it to make everyone realize how much like Will they are.  Math may not be your strong point or your weak point either, but this characteristic of Will is simply an example of a trait that could cause any type of tension or problems in the life of a person.  I especially love how Williams' character is written into this same theme so that personalities young and old clash. This is one of few movies that can truly move me emotionally every time I see it, and it is because it can be related to every human that ever lived.

title: Smart, funny and touching but not perfect
review: I've watched this movie about 5 times and I have to say I really love this movie! It's about life and growing up! There are some very touching scenes with clever dialogue and GOOD acting. Robin Williams is perfect as the psychologist and Matt Damon is trustworthy, so is Ben Affleck. Minnie Diver is also acting good and you can truly say that it's something between them, the only bad thing is her laugh! But there are some flaws that makes this film not as perfect as it could have been. The fighting scene are just ridiculous and Casey Affleck is acting a little bit too "dumb". Cole Hauser isn't saying anything at all! Stellan SkarsgÃ¥rd is not convincing as a professor, especially in the scene where he thinks that the answer is wrong but Will says it's right and set the paper on fire. And there is something with his accent.. Anyway, apart from some stupid scenes this is a touching film! The ending is also very good, it's just so genuine! I gave this 8 out of 10.

title: awe-inspiring!
review: If I don't like a movie, I'm very flat and vocal about expressing my opinion; but this movie here was terrific... great acting and direction but overall this piece of fiction leaves a person moved for the rest of their lives. I can still cite some incidents where I have judged my actions based on the philosophy preached by this movie. A must see for all generations especially the younger generations!

title: one of the best ever
review: Simply one of the best movies ever produced.  Incredibly moving, razor sharp, beautiful, strong, life-affirming. Great sound track, too.  Best career performance of Williams and probably every other actor in the cast. Incredible piece of work.  Will stand the test of time.

title: Isn't great that shrinks always have the answers?
review: Let's see, will has a brain the size of the universe, but he just sits around in his apartment drinking beer and reading undergraduate textbooks. He's never had a real relationship, but we're supposed to feel that Minnie Driver should fall in love with him because...well, for some reason or other.  He sees her as a way of proving himself superior to the wealthier types actually enrolled at a university, but, well, we just know that underneath he's got a heart of gold...God knows why... Wait; am I actually supposed to like this guy?  Even Minnie Driver's character doesn't seem to; she's more like someone having a polite good time with a mere acquaintance than any sort of potential girlfriend.  Even Robin Williams character seems to see Will as basically negative, if excusably so, and his portrayal of an incredibly nice guy almost proves that Will needed that just to relate to others.  This film is not about an interesting character, "darn" it!  It's about a jerk who we have to assume to have some redeeming something-or-other inside him.

title: Excellent movie...
review: Good Will Hunting is one of the best movies I have ever seen!! Matt Damon is just wonderful! One of his best movies. If you haven't seen this movie, you need to see this movie!! I rate this movie as a 10!!!

title: A great Film
review: This is one of the best films I've seen to date. I've watched it three times in a row and if I ever picked it off the shelf I'd watch it three times again. Very good with the best speeches ever, The cast is great, very funny -dont listen to stupid people's opions on it, they have no freedom of speach in my view. See it now!

title: Amazing Masterpiece
review: I watched Good Will Hunting and I was quite amazed at how the movie turned out. Upon watching traliers I figured it would be a cliche show but boy was I wrong!!!. The acting was excellent, Robin Williams and Matt Damon play their best roles ever as a struggling shrink coping with the loss of his wife and a genius from Southie (yes it is possible). Cole Hauser, Ben & Casey Affleck and Minnie Driver are excellent as Will's friends. I also liked the fact that they put a little bit of baseball history in the movie (Pudge Fisk) as well as many humourous lines. For a movie that catapoulted 2 unknown actors (Affleck & Damon) into superstardom, i rate it 10 out of 10 :) so if you like apples, then i suggest you watch this Masterpiece of a film, then you can tell me how much you like them apples!!!

title: Never get tired of a good story
review:
I never saw this movie in the cinema. I regret this. Many months later, after the hype subsided, I decided to rent the movie on video. What I watched was a thoroughly entertaining story!

It's this kind of story that is simple enough to get enticed straight away and real enough that you don't lose interset half way through.

The real hook for Good Will Hunting, though, is Robin Williams performance. He was good in 'Awakenings' and even better in 'Dead Poets Society', but never better than here as the burnt out councillor who hasn't been challenged in years. He finally meets his match in Will Hunting (Matt Damon).

There are many sub-plots in this story, but the ones that will make you sit up and take notice will be the exchanges between Will Hunting and Sean (Robin Williams).

There are also many fine supporting performances, some of which have never been bettered in other movies. Stellan Skarsgard is convincing as the pretentious, insecure MIT professor. Ben Affleck also delivers his best performance to date as the ever loyal, Chuckie. Perhaps the only let down performance is by Minnie Driver.

Overall, It's the kind of movie you can sit and watch time and time again and never get tired of.

I rate it 10 out of 10.

title: Very good movie
review: I want more.  It ended too soon.  Every actor was wonderful.  I loved the chemistry between the the Afflecks, Damon, and Houser.  I have watched this movie over and over, and it just seems to get better.  A must see!!!!!!!!! 10 out of 10 stars.

title: Very Good Drama
review: This Film was a good drama story with a cast and writing team. Ben Affleck Acted in And Wrote this Movie Were Great. Ben's Brother Casey acted in this Aswell Robin Willams was good as the man who helped Will Hunting And Minne Driver Add A touch of British Class to this Movie

title: In the end, the book would've been better.
review:
I remember seeing this movie with my dad at the movies back in '97. I remember how it hit my stomach and made me shiver, and how I returned to the cinema the very next day to watch it again.

The moment I got it on video, I watched it every day after school. It was a great movie and I loved it. I cried. I laughed. It was a movie about life.

But now, after having seen the movie too many times, every line is like a quote and I'm thinking, this should be a book. I'd rather read the script over and over again than watching the movie another time. Don't get me wrong though, the movie's great, but I think the book would've been better.

This is the movie about Will Hunting, an intelligent kid with a disturbing childhood. Because of his childhood he has psychological issues and does not function well, but thanks to a job he got through his parole officer, he gets in touch with a math professor who takes him under his wings, but what will this mean and how will Will handle it all?

It's clearly a brilliant movie about troubled minds, growing up, and how we're all different in similar ways. Watch this movie once or twice, but refrain from watching it too many times.

***/*****

title: Definitely Worth Renting!!
review: I just have to recommend this movie to anyone who was wondering whether or not it's worth it. It's so refreshing to see a movie that has characters that have depth and are believable as human beings. The acting and script was wonderful...everything a good movie should be.

title: A thought about the language
review:
Stepping on soapbox...

Clearly a lot of people think that the use of the F-word in this film was borderline criminal, unrealistic and offensive. I'd just like to set the record straight.

1) Having grown up and worked in the Boston suburbs, I've found that the film accurately portrayed the way young men talk with each other, swearing and all. Anyone who doesn't believe this simply hasn't been to Southie or Revere or Lynn or any of the other working class towns in Eastern Mass. You may not like it, but it IS realistic.

2) What's to be offended at? They're not swearing AT you. They're not even swearing at each other. They use the words not to offend, but as part of their group palare. It's part of the culture that binds them. They're not even real words as they convey no meaning. They're more like interjections.

If you're offended by the use of words, I ask you to examine what exactly you're afraid of.

Stepping off soapbox...

title: Excellent AND Entirely Possible
review:
Despite the odd comments by one fellow here who claims to be a mathematician; This was not only an excellent movie but an entirely believable one. Not just believable but IMPORTANTLY so.

Contrary to our mad rush to find the minimal acceptable and attempt to improve the self image of the mediocre, Talent DOES exist. It could be, should be, thought of as the key attribute of man.

And truly talented people CAN teach themselves anything and everything - I learned early in life to use the word genius with caution, when a frustrated (and slightly jealous) teacher said to me as a precocious pre-teen "It is not enough to be a genius (Very High IQ) you have to be a genius AT something" - and that is true, so I will not describe Will as a genius but very talented. One salient point of the movie was Will's trave(ai)l from talent - IQ genius - to being a genius AT something. You know as he's driving off in the wonderful gift from Affleck (who I did think was very impressive, maybe a touch more than Matt) THAT was to become the quest, the search for his proper role / accomplishment / (and yes, contribution). Even though we are encouraged to think it is Mini Driver he seeks, it is himself and that ultimate of all, creative accomplishment (as mathematics can be as creative as sculpture and music).

This understanding and acknowledgement of original talent is also discouraged as we have turned `Education' into a self serving, institutionalized, industry that sells knowledge rather than disseminating it.

One of the best lines in the movie is when Will tells an imitation scholar student that he will eventually discover, if his parents haven't already, that they are spending thousands (hundreds of thousands) to teach him things that can be bought by a talented person with three dollars in overdue book fines from the library.

Perhaps that was what made it such a great movie for me, I've been there, all of it, South Boston and the hallowed halls on Mass Avenue.

I started sitting in college class rooms - auditing - while still a young teen. Had to play hooky from ridiculous `High' School to do it. In fact, I can even appreciate Will's `attitude' as today's society evermore dedicates itself to conformity and forcing same regardless of talent.

Made a pain-in-the-a!! of myself by correcting the professors and knowing the answers before anyone else. Never paid a dime in tuition (even ignoring a bill for campus parking in Cambridge) and got tested out as a Masters in Engineering (by a short lived program from the ASME that was undoubtedly squelched by academia because they weren't getting their piece of flesh).

I DO know whereof I speak, and the `mathematician' is just another one of those jealous of talent.

THIS IS A VERY GOOD, if not downright great, MOVIE!

title: Matt & Ben should write more scripts!
review: I think it is safe to say that anyone who has seen this movie will wonder how two young actors managed to write such a beautiful and realistic story, with characters you can relate to despite the fact that one of them is an overlooked math genius. Add to that creditable performances from everyone involved (esp. Robin Williams in semi-dramatic mode), good directing and wonderful musical contribution from Elliott Smith (who was unfortunate not to win a Grammy for "Miss Misery"), and you have one of the most endearing movies ever. You can tell right away from the first scene that Matt Damon and Ben Affleck are the bestest of friends, and they have several poignant scenes in this movie. Minnie Driver was good as well, and you have to feel for her character. Well, like I said before...those two really should write more scripts, who knows what other stories are stored away in their heads. Watch this movie if you haven't already!

title: Great movie!!A must see!!
review:
This is such a good movie it's unbelievable!!! It is a mix of humor,tragedy and romance-very well rounded. I must admit I was not interested at all in seeing it, even after it won the Oscar. Most Oscar winning movies aren't worthy...but this one is! I was at my friends house sleeping over, it was about 2 in the morning, and i could not take my eyes off the screen. This movie is amazing, although the cursing gets a bit much, it adds to the feeling and tone of the movie. It also helps that Matt Damon, Ben Affleck and Casey Affleck originate from the area, making it more realistic.

Damon, Williams, Driver and Affleck all deliver touching performances that really make you relate to them. The story is awesome and I highly recommend it!!

title: Excellent movie...
review: Good Will Hunting is an excellent movie that provides a real celebration of the human spirit.  Will Hunting is an everyday Joe, who works as a janitor in some college. Despite his meager lifestyle, Will (played by matt damon) is extremely bright and has a gifted and interesting outlook on a number of things. He ends up being sent to a psychatrist, played by Robin Williams, and thus a story about this young man unfolds. Despite very strong language and some crude humor, you start to get inside this guy's head and really relate to him.  Underneath his hard shell is just this soft, sensitive guy wanting to be loved.  With best friend played by Ben Afflek, who encourages him to get up and leave his life as a shmuck, and girlfriend, played by Minnie Driver, who loves him, he starts to realize he could be making something of himself. A truimphant ending will leave you with bittersweet tears. A stifling performance by the whole cast who was wonderfully chosen. 9 out of ten!!!!!!

title: I really enjoyed this well-written movie.
review: I thought that Ben Affleck and Matt Damon did a tremendously good job writing this movie. They both also did a good job acting in it. I also thought that Robin Williams deserved that Academy Award for Best Supporting Actor because he did an excellent job. Someone might wonder, do they really need to swear that much? But they do because Will and his friends are supposed to be living a tough life and you imagine that they would swear a lot. So because they do swear so much, that proves that Ben and Matt are very good writers and in my opinion they should write more scripts in the future, whether it's together or separate, even though they probably would do better together. So over all this movie was one of the best movies I've seen in a long time.

title: I had a harder time than others with this movie
review: An incredibly handsome working class boy with little formal education who knows absolutely everything and can outthink the finest university mathematician is not unlikely--it is impossible.  Take it from a mathematician.  If you care for a shred of credibility in your movies, forget this one.  It is pure fantasy, as is the director's other shamelessly self-indulgent movie, the low-budget "My Own Private Idaho."

title: Beautiful Movie
review:
Very rarely does a movie stand out like this one. Matt Damon and Ben Affleck's story is so beautiful that you experience every type of emotion throughout the film.

Robin Williams deserved the Oscar for his performance and it's sad that people often forget that when he does a serious film - he's brilliant. He doesn't showcase that other side of him often enough and he's probably the only actor besides Bruce Willis who can play every type of character imaginable.

Matt Damon and Ben Affleck were brilliant as well and deserved more recognition at the Oscars other than the win for the screenplay.

I am not a fan of Minnie Driver but her performance is haunting and she really put all her heart and soul into this role.

If you haven't seen this movie you don't know what you are missing.

title: I like this film
review:
I really must recommend this film, I had seen it once before on TV but I had been staying up way to late many nights leading up to the film and fell asleep :(..

Now that I have got the film Ive watched it whilst not so fatigued and wow yes sir, good all rounder, the Actors are very believable and satisfying ... Full of intelligent whit and filmed beautifully :) yes 8-10 for me :) watching again some time this year

title: A good editor away from being a masterpiece!
review: I like the way I felt after I finished watching this film. Not in a happy Hollywood ending kind of way, more of a contented put my feet up thing. These days it seems that a film is either transparently contrived as a money making vehicle, pretentiously aimed at being an art piece or just plain bad! It was nice to see an excellent story done in an above average way! My only regret is that a few scenes were not left on the editing room floor. For example why was the "don't masturbate in my moms room scene there". Not because of the subject matter but because A: it wasn't interesting or well done and B: It had no connection with anything else that happened. It could have replaced with another interaction scene between Damon and Driver so that when all the, "I love you's" started flying around I wasn't left scratching my head and thinking, already! You may think I didn't like this flick. Wrong, it was excellent and I give it a nine!

title: One of the most boring movies I have seen in my whole life
review: I love Robin Williams and believe he's the greatest actor in the whole world.  I collect his movies and watch them over and over again.   However, I didn't like GWH at all.  It's impossible for me to understand how this movie got so many positive reviews.  I found it boring and silly at the same time.

title: Great script, acting, but diminished by "Hollywood Style"
review:
GOOD WILL HUNTING is a very good movie. The writing, credited to Mssrs. Afleck and Damon, is among the best I can remember in a recent American film. Mr Afleck appears to have benefited from the script of CHASING AMY or vice-versa. Robin Williams' role as the burned out shrink ties everything together to make this a memorable story. I wish he would do more of this type of material and less clowning.

However, the credible story, realistic characters, and excellent script beautifully played by the cast are restrained by a glossy presentation. Anyone familiar with the coastal Northeast (story takes place in Boston) knows overcast skies, wind, rain. The relentless sunshine bathes the story in a California like light but with gritty old Boston as the backdrop. Doesn't work.

Nitpicking? Probably, but this film is very close to being as good as movies get and every little misstep becomes magnified as a result.

title: So Boring!!!!!!
review: After hearing people rant and rave about how terrific this movie was....some even saying when it came out in home video they were going to BUY a copy, not just rent it, I figured it had to be a terrific movie.  Boy, was I ever led down the garden path.  The only GOOD thing about it was familiar scenery in Boston.  The premise of a lowly janitor solving complex mathematical problems was a good one.  But once the viewer found that out, then what? Nothing happens at all....just a bunch of video filling, time wasting pablum puke.  The plot completely fell apart so that you are left with, "Okay, so the janitor is a genius, now what?  What does he do with this capability? Anything?  No....NOTHING!!!"  I want my $6.75 back PLUS damages!!!  What a total waste of two hours!!!

title: Mediocre first effort
review: So I hear everyone talking about this great movie by two young up and coming actors looking for work and how awesome this movie is.  And so, I go and I see Good Will Hunting.  Now I know why Matt Damon was struggling to find work. I bought the screenplay and read it before I ever saw the movie and the screenplay itself is great.  I've read it many times since and each time, I still love it.  However, for some reason, the executives at Miramax failed to see that letting Damon and also Minnie Driver have roles in this movie would be a mistake.  Affleck is a good actor, although his part sucks in this movie but Damon went and wrote a whole story about his character and then failed to deliver. There were a few positives.  The friendship between Affleck and Damon does spill over into the movie and it does leave an impression.  Robin Williams is great.  I mean, the man can do anything. Comedy, drama, anything.  But the rest of the cast is pretty much mediocre except for Ben Affleck who also was good in Chasing Amy. In all, this movie was OK but nowhere near as good as the hype made it out to be.  The screenplay is definitely worth buying but the acting in the movie itself pretty much sucks.

title: Good Film
review: Good Will Hunting is a very special film to me. The thing I love about this film is the relationship factor, the way relationships develop throughout the film - between Will and Sean, Will and Skylar, Will and Chuckie. I also like the way we see Will grow through the film and especially the way Sean and Will overcome their grief together. I thought Minnie Driver was illuminous throughout the film, Damon was excellent as Will, and Robin Williams deserved his Oscar. The film made me cry a lot as well.

title: Great Characterization, needs a little more.....
review: Perhaps many people have placed too much emphasis on this movie.  I am not saying this in a derogatory way.  The characterization in this movie is brilliant.  Matt Damon and Robin Williams give outstanding performances, although they do become a little predictable by the time that the movie is over.  Perhaps this movie is just that: a characterization.  The plot allows us to look at a man that is intelligent; far more intelligent than the average MIT student (as supposedly proved in the theorem-solving part of the movie).  Like an action movie star, the main character allows us to look at someone that is unlike us.  This goes for the character that Williams plays. We look at a psychologist with a type of awe: perhaps they see an insight into the human psyche that no one can (supposedly).  The problem is that: the movie is full of characterization.  Even though there are a few people that Damon plays running around the streets, we look into his life, and are forced to like him.  Going out on a limb, I am saying that this movie is like a Steinbeck book: the characterization is superb, but the other elements are lacking.  Don't let this movie escape you though, it is worth seeing the characterization alone.  By the time the movie is over, you will feel that you know the people intimately.  That is the reason that I give this movie a 6.8 out of 10

title: The best movie I have ever seen.
review: This movie was one of the best movies I have ever seen.The containment of showing the life of a young man, but showing how and what they do and go through in life. This one of the few movies that actually made me cry. This is what I consider a movie that you can relate or connect to yourself. I wish the movie companies would more movies like this.

title: Genius? Possibly.
review:
I rented this movie not expecting it to live up to hype. I had not heard one person say a bad word about this film and they were absolutely right. Damon's character is complex and involving, sometimes even quite humorous. The on screen chemistry between him and Affleck is a joy to watch, Affleck being far less intelligent than Damon's character yet having more common sense and seeing that Will Hunting was just wasting himself is an interesting angle.

In my opinion, Robin Williams is one of the most under-rated serious drama actors, though gaining plaudits for his comedy work this is as good as his excellent role in 'Dead Poet's Society' and the dialogue between him and Damon is spectacular. It kept me interested throughout the film and brought sympathy to an arrogant character. The only element to keep this film from perfection was that Will Hunting's attitude change was perhaps too sudden, other than that a fine movie that I'd recommend to anyone who likes a good storyline.

title: Titanic who???
review: I loved this movie.  I absolutely loved it.  I was fascinated by every single aspect of it.  Sure, the plot wasn't the most realistic, but who cares?  Movies are entertainment, and that's all.  The profanity was not that excessive if you spend any time at all with many lower to middle-class people around the age of the characters.  In fact, it was downright realistic. As for the acting, it was wonderful watching Damon portray this character who has to struggle with what he thinks he wants, what he is told he should want, and what he finally realizes he really wants.  No, I don't think it was the best performance of the year, but it was definitely one of the top five and worthy of a Best Actor nomination.  The chemistry between him and Minnie Driver was electric, particularly during their first date and again in the scene in her apartment before he leaves.  Robin Williams, in my opinion, delivers his best performance.  Sure, it's the typical Williams-drama character from Dead Poets Society and the like, but this character was better with the mental games and interactions with Will.  The best part of this movie was watching the relationship develop between Will and Sean.  This wasn't an epic movie, nothing too profound, but it was a small movie about love, relationships, and finding yourself, and in this capacity I think it was wonderful.  9.5 out of 10.

title: Typical Oscar Nominee
review: "Good Will Hunting" (1997:***). For awhile, I didn't think I was going to like this movie; there are too many clay-pigeon stupid jerks introduced simply to be demolished by the superhuman intelligence of Will Hunting (hated that bar scene, especially). It's a relief when Robin Williams finally shows up as his therapist, because you sense that this cocky but self-destructive kid has finally met his match.  The heart of the picture is the prickly relationship between these two, even though it does lead to the inevitable (and still potent) breakdown scene in which the mixed-up young man cries on his therapist's shoulder (e.g., "Ordinary People," "Prince of Tides," etc.).  There are almost as many scenes in this movie that don't work as do (the dreadful one in which Hunting substitutes Ben Affleck, as his best friend, for himself in a job interview should have been cut). But a good supporting cast and some tangy Boston atmosphere helps, and Matt Damon finally does win you over.  This is also one of Robin Williams' best dramatic performances.  He really anchors the film.  I'd be interested to know how much input he (and others) had on the original screenplay written by Damon and Affleck. All-in-all pretty good.

title: A wonderful, moving experience.
review:
Starting slow but interesting, I found the story utterly absorbing and emotionally moving (which is, unfortunately, quite rare with me). For me it was one of those movies that you check your watch and pray it's not over yet -- it's not a story you watch to bring you from Point A to Point B -- it's the going that's good. It's a well-written, well-acted story with deep characters that you care about.

Even the least-developed main relationship, Will and Skylar's, was profound. The torment that Will brought her in the end merely reflects his own, and you can feel that.

I'd love to see a sequal (Better Will Hunting?) to see what they do with Will/Skylar. If it were true to life, it'd have her telling him to shove-off, but that'd make for a pretty short movie.

title: Much ado about "NOTHING"...
review: This was one of the most disappointing films in a long time.  After all the hype and people going on about this film I finally watched it and left the theatre convinced those other people were talking about another film.  The script was extremely clichéd, characters so unreal and situations out of a bad after school special.  I enjoyed Ben Affleck and Matt Damon's other roles (notably Chasing Amy & Rainmaker) but this was terrible.  There were simply too many unanswered questions and ridiculous events.  Next time Hollywood wants to feed us this crap, they should take into account that we are all not so moronic to eat it up.

title: Deep insight into human relationships
review: I love this movie for its depth of insight into human relationships. I am amazed that two young men could write this film. Yes, I could do without the continual bombardment of foul language, but I believe it to be honest to who the characters are. I am saddened to read comments from other viewers who seemed to have completely missed the point. And for those folks who pointed out in the "Goofs" listings all the math errors they could find, put down your slide rules and calculators and notice the people in the film! It's a shame this movie came out the same year as "Titanic," because it deserves Best Picture. I bought this video because its message touched me deeply.

title: Loved It
review: I came in to this movie not expecting much, but what I got was a powerful movie that taught me that talent should never be wasted.  Will Hunting is a man gifted with phenomenal intelligence.  He lives alone in Boston and spends his days hanging out with his friends, drinking beer, and beating up old bullies.  He supports himself with part time jobs like janitor work. When a college professor discovers that Will Hunting is a genius like no other, he decides to exploit him by offering him top rate jobs that would give him access to great prestige.  Will Hunting's therapist, played outstandingly by Robin Williams, want's Will to do what he wants and not be forced to go out into the world and change his entire lifestyle.  The movie follows Will Hunting as he matures from a scared defensive kid, to a man able to discover what path to take in his life. Great movie.   9/10

title: Thought-provoking!
review: This is a very serious, thought-provoking, and somewhat improbable psycho-drama.  A little romance, much anger, some violence,  many memorable lines, and way too much profanity.  Is that what life's really like in South Boston?

title: I don't wish to sound patronising, but this is a good first try.
review: Excellent performances from most of the cast, realistic dialogue, solid direction(From Gus Van Sant who has worked on "My Own Private Idaho" and "Drugstore Cowboy"), and some powerful moments make this 1997 Oscar winner(for Screenplay) watchable. The screenplay, for my mind was the problem. It's a good debut, but it's too familiar(eg. "Educating Rita" and the novel "Maestro" By Peter Goldsworthy"). It's your typical teacher-student film. My brother would like it to be known that I was wrong about the ending, but I wasn't totally wrong, Damon and Ben Affleck are rock solid, and Robin Williams richly deserved his Oscar for another nicely subdued performance(it's a pity he's always playing doctor types). Stellan Skarsgaard and particularly Minnie Driver(sporting her real english accent, which sounds more superficial than her irish or american) are irritating, however. Driver gets a huge laugh though in one scene. Ben and his brother Casey Affleck also have funny moments, as does Matt Damon(a bit egotistical to put himself in the lead, though). Nice, but we've seen it all before.

title: Troubled Genius
review: Good Will Hunting is a brilliant film.  It is very well made and written. The performances are great.  The story is wonderful.  Two powerful scenes stand out.  Chucky telling Will he is crazy for squandering his gift and Will and Sean embracing toward the end.  GWH is a terrific film.

title: Enjoy the good lines.
review: Good Will Hunting really should have been a play. This is not to say that it wasn´t a good movie, because it still does move very well and the cinematography was excellent.  However, the real joy of the movie is not so much in the visual effects, as in, for example, Saving Private Ryan, but in the dialogue.

title: True Character. . .
review:
Good Will Hunting is not about twist endings, drawn-out action scenes, or even a sappy romance. It has been knocked for being too predictable and trying to hard to pull the heart strings of its audience. . .

Both are true.

Still, the main reason this may be one of the best movies of the 90's is the deep, moving characters that Gus Van Sant has created. The characters YOU know.

Each and every character is someone I know or can relate too. The genius who isn't living up to his potential. The man who has based everything he is on the woman he loved. The people who see the magic in someone, and can't stand to let it go to waste. Even the professor's assistant, the wonder kid whose been knocked of the top rung by a new wonder kid, I can relate to.

Let it be known that the movie is going to turn out *exactly* the way you want it to. And let it be known that you'll probably have a tear in your eye before the credits roll. . .

I wouldn't have it any other way.

title: Matt Damon gives a top-notch performance in "...
review: Matt Damon gives a top-notch performance in "Good Will Hunting," as does the Oscar-winning Robin Williams. The great job of un-showy directing keeps the attention on the story. A heart-warming movie with a tight, award-winning script and wonderful acting. Not recommended for those who cannot stomach crude sexual humor. B

title: excellent movie
review: Good Will Hunting is exactly what I've been waiting for. A nice intelligent movie that is dramatic yet funny. I think that this movie shows the wonderful talent of Matt Damon and Ben Affleck not only as actors but as writers. I'm sure it will be a favorite movie for years to come. I would even go as far as to say that one day, many years from now, it will be considered a great classic.

title: Couldn't miss a minute!
review: This is one of the better movies I have seen in a long time.  The movie holds your attention the entire time.  It also shows that good guys don't have to finish last.  The only problem I see is that the language could have been cleaned up.  I don't understand why that can't be left out of great movies so everyone can enjoy them.

title: Bellissimo!
review: It is a wonderful film.I can't say all I want because I'm not so good in English but I want only to advise all of you to watch it because I've liked it a lot.That's all.

title: A movie that truly has something to talk about
review:
Before i saw "Good Will Hunting' in the cinema i was hearing about a new talent called Matt Damon who starred and wrote one of the best pictures of 1997. But it was until i saw it that i aggred with all this comments. Good Will Hunting has one of the most original screenplays of the last decade and it's not surprising the fact that its fans are mostly young people. It deals with a very serious matter and manages to examine its every aspect. It's a fresh and original movie, the kind of those we want to see more in the cinemas. Matt Damon is of course the core and the soul of this picture. He co-wrote the screenplay with Ben Affleck and managed to persuade the 'big-bosses" to make it a great movie. Demon is excellent in the lead and truly deserved the Oscar as his portrayal of Will was utterly realistic.

Robin Williams is equally impressive in the role of the doctor and proves that he can be better in drama than in comedy. But the true revelation of the picture is the great Minnie Driver. She too gives a realistic and heart-warming performance that allows her to be regarded as the most talented actresses today.(Her performances in "Grosse Point Blank" and especially in "The Circle of Friends" also prove that) Good Will Hunting is along with "The Wings of the Dove" undoubtedly the best picture of 1997.

title: Challenge yourself and get a life....
review:
When first watching "GWH" at a theater in Chicago I walked out of it after an hour. The dialogue was so hard to understand being used to subtitles in Sweden. I couldn't hear or understand half of what was said on the screen and since this is a dialogue driven movie it simply made the whole experience unbearable. Arriving back to Sweden I thought I'd give it another chance (with subtitles this time mind you) and surprisingly I loved it. The premise might be stereotype and cliche, but tell me what movie that isn't. It's HOW the story is told that ultimately counts. "Good Will Hunting" is basically a "coming of age" movie, but with such well written dialogue and characters that one truly believes in them. The pace is very slow and that fact does the movie good actually. We're not watching a John Hughes movie here.

I can't really understand why so many people who have submitted their opinions on "GWH" finds the language so foul and ugly. There isn't more "F***" than in any other drama, action or war movie.

The foul language isn't in the movie for show, it's there to flesh out the characters. The fact is that people often use the F-word a lot in real life. Why not in movies then?

All and all, Good Will Hunting manages to be both dramatic and funny with some lovable characters and great performances from SkarsgÃ¥rd, Williams, Damon , Drive and Affleck. This is a movie that could be mention in the same sentence as "Dead Poet's Society" and not only because Robin Williams is in it.

title: Language
review:
To those who say that removing the language wouldn't have made it any less real:

bullsh....wait, sorry. Seriously, though, the language in this movie is as close to 100% accurate as any movie I've seen in a while. I'll admit that I grew up in a white-collar household, but I have had many friends over the years from blue-collar backgrounds. Both groups swear a lot. I mean a LOT. Young people, when among themselves and with people who won't be offended, tend to relax their speech. Now, is this perhaps an indictment of those young people? Depends on who you ask. But don't attack a film for a fairly realistic account of dialogue between South Boston twenty-somethings. The fault I would find on the dialogue is the snappiness of delivery, but that's the movies. Cleaning up rough dialogue just wouldn't ring as true in my opinion.

title: a good movie, but hype unjustified
review: While I enjoyed this movie, I think all the hype was unjustified. Matt Damon was somehow unconvincing in this role, though he is an extremely talented actor (perhaps this is due to the unbelievable plot). Robin Williams' performance as the troubled psychiatrist was nothing short of brilliant, and to me, was the best (and most underrated) thing about this movie. The movie did not engage my emotions as I believe it should have. I could not help thinking how hard it seemed to try to be a cross between "Forrest Gump" and "Ordinary People," and as a result proved inferior to both. Also features a memorable performance by Skellan (sorry, forgot the last name!) as a mathematics professor but I did not care for the annoying Minnie Driver as Damon's love interest. The ending was also somehow unsatisfying.  Did "Will" ever make anything of himself or not? One wonders...

title: Understanding all that the director would like the...
review: Understanding all that the director would like the public to swallow, this movie is vulgar and preaches a lack of responsibility --"it's not my fault- -I am a victim, therefore I can do and say as I please".

title: Realism and fantasy blended with snappy dialogue
review:
GWH stands out as soon as the actors breathe their first lines of dialogue, Matt Damon's character has been given some of the sparkiest lines in recent memory. Overall the language used is in keeping with the location and the setting in both the upper (Harvard) and lower (South Boston) parts of the city.

I am really amazed about the number of complaints about the use of colourful language, this sort of dialogue is necessary to portray Will and friends realistically, to leave it out would be like taking the soldiers out of Saving Private Ryan or the food out of Babette's Feast.

Let's not be too hard on the writers for using a well used plot line, in the end everything is derivative and the story does offer an excellent portrayal of the way success is measured, the loneliness experienced by the intellectually gifted and how knowledge does not necessarily guarantee wisdom.

title: High Concept college movie
review: Good Will Hunting is an enjoyable look at life through the eyes of two screenwriters who seem upset at the lack of recognition for the talent they feel they have. It follows the three act high concept paradigm ( or formula ) to the letter. Act.1 Introduce the Character  Act.2 Put the Character through a test  Act.3 Watch the character redeem himself. The film is a metaphor for the lives of Affleck and Damon. Two kids that feel they are talented actors / filmmakers who haven't been recognised, dream about 'what if we could prove ourselves to be more talented than those with better credentials.' If we could beat the MIT maths professor without having to study. The irony is that they did prove it, they won an Oscar. This film is basically Top Gun set in academia.

title: You're missing something
review: I'm not trying to wax Siskel & Ebert here.  The movie caught my attention during the credits!  It was refreshing to view a movie, that no matter how unrealistic, still pulled at your heartstrings.  Come on, twenty-something is almost as bad as Junior High.  Watching the movie made me think that maybe I wasn't the only one questioning life in general.  If it didn't make you think for just one nano-second, then I'm sorry.  You totally missed something...

title: Hype not justified, but not a bad movie
review: I just don't see why this movie was such a popular hit, not to mention an Oscar contender for best picture.  Granted, the story was original and deserving of some credit, but not exactly the claimed "shot in the arm of originality" the industry needed. It is a joy to watch, filled with many humorous moments.  The explicit swearing doesn't take away from the movie; rather, it adds to regional aura the audience is meant to feel from South Bostonites.  That joke that Skylar tells about the old couple is the funniest I've heard in a long time.
